Each traffic flow is defined by the source and destination of the IPv4 address and port, by the direction of the traffic, as well as by the TCP or UDP communications protocol.

Communications Policies can be set on traffic flows while building the Stealth(aware) Model, as follows:
By defaults defined at the Project or Profile level
By the user manually on individual Profiles or traffic flows
A group of Stealth endpoints that can communicate securely. You create COIs using Enterprise Manager, and then assign them for use by users and groups.
Configurations represent Stealth communication based on the roles, COIs, filters, users, and groups that you define. You can set up one or more configurations in your environment.
The group of computers that communicate over a Stealth-enabled network.
A computer (workstation or server) that participates in a Stealth-enabled network. This can be a virtual machine or physical server. An endpoint runs the Stealth endpoint software.
An Internet standard that enables a local-area network (LAN) to use one group of IP addresses for internal traffic and a different group of IP addresses for external traffic.
Any device or user identity in the computing environment.
The rule for communications over individual traffic flows. There are three available policies: to allow clear text traffic, to allow Stealth traffic, or to block all traffic.

A container for devices that perform a similar function; for example, Web Servers, Application Servers, and Database Servers. Profiles are defined on the Stealth(aware) Map through an automated Affinitization of the network traffic flows recorded during Stealth Discovery and then sorted into Profiles using the auto modeling process. You can also manually create a Profile.

Affinitization identifies those devices that include similar traffic flows to other devices, which enables Stealth(aware) to create Profiles that combine similar devices into a single object. During the process of creating Profiles, individual devices (for example, Web Servers) are also auto-classified using a Heuristics Analysis of the traffic data to and from each device.
A Profile that is the basis, or root, of a Stealth(aware) Solution.

A combination of the Unisys proprietary Secure Community of Interest Protocol combined with a standard Internet Protocol Security, which is used to encrypt and authenticate each IP packet of a communication session.
An application stack; for example, an order processing, ERP, or HR application.

The Stealth(aware) Affinitization and auto modeling process identifies those devices and user identities (Nodes) in the network that have frequent communications with each other, and are therefore likely to represent a single application stack. A Solution is comprised of Profiles and their connecting Channels.

A network over which data is encrypted using the Unisys proprietary Secure Community of Interest Protocol combined with a standard Internet Protocol Security to encrypt and authenticate each IP packet of a communication session. (This combination of protocols is known as SCIP/IPsec.)

A computer that is monitored by Enterprise Manager. This could be a Management Server, standalone Authorization Server, Secure Remote Access (SRA) Gateway, Secure Virtual Gateway, or Stealth 2.8 Appliance.

A Stealth endpoint communication path in the environment. There are two types of tunnels: unicast and multicast. A unicast tunnel is a point-to-point communication path between a unique pair of nodes. A multicast tunnel is a multipoint communication path among a set of member endpoints.

chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: Unisys Stealth(aware) is the visual front-end for Stealth(core), which provides network security by cloaking data from detection as it moves through the network. Stealth(aware) is designed to automatically discover network traffic and creates an interactive map of the network topology. It is an augmented knowledge discovery tool that can be used to help you understand the traffic flows in your environment, and then to automate the configuration of Stealth(core) in order to protect your network. Stealth(aware) simplifies and expedites the creation of micro-segmentation rules and enhances your understanding of your network.

note.para: Stealth(aware) cannot be used to modify Stealth configurations that you created using Enterprise Manager or that you created using Stealth(aware) and then updated using Enterprise Manager. For more information on using Enterprise Manager, see the Unisys Stealth Solution Information Center.

chapter.para: Stealth(aware) enables you to auto-discover your network communications, auto-model groups based on their traffic patterns, and auto-deploy Stealth policies to Enterprise Manager and the appropriate Stealth endpoints. Stealth(aware) simplifies the deployment of Stealth onto your network, compared to exclusively using Enterprise Manager, and enables you to deploy a new Stealth configuration quickly and easily in your network.

section.title: Configuration Requirements for Integrating with Stealth(core)
section.para:
In order to use Stealth(aware), your environment must meet the following requirements for integrating with Stealth(core):
You must have a new environment in which to deploy Stealth.
Using Stealth(aware) in an existing Stealth environment is not supported in this release, and there is no upgrade path that includes use of Stealth(aware). That is, there should be no existing Stealth Management Server, standalone Authorization Servers, or Stealth endpoints in the network in which you want to configure Stealth(aware); you are directed to create these new components later in this book.
However, if you have an existing Stealth environment and want to use Stealth(aware), you could configure a separate network in which to deploy a new Stealth environment (for example, a new test environment).
You must use the Management Server to authorize all endpoints. (Standalone Authorization Servers are not supported in this release.)
Your Management Server must have a static IPv4 address.
Your environment must use IPv4 addressing.
You must use all default certificates created by Enterprise Manager, including the default Signing certificate (and its associated Trusted Root certificate) and the default Authorization Service certificates.
Your endpoint users must be included in Active Directory groups in order to be authorized. This means that the Management Server must belong to an Active Directory domain. In addition, the Active Directory server must either be Stealth-enabled, or the Management Server and endpoints must include clear text filters to the Active Directory server.
(For endpoint authorization, local users and Active Directory users are not supported for this release; only Active Directory groups are supported.)
You must authorize all endpoints using Integrated Windows Authentication. (LDAP and certificate-based authorization are not supported in this release.)
You must have a datacenter configuration that does not require use of the Secure Remote Access (SRA) Gateway or the Secure Virtual Gateway.

If your environment does not meet these requirements, you must use Enterprise Manager to configure your Stealth environment, including creating and provisioning configurations, COIs, roles, users, and groups. See the Unisys Stealth Solution Information Center for more information.

section.title: Understanding Stealth(aware)
section.para: The following topics help you understand Stealth(aware).

section.title: Stealth(aware) Overview
section.para: Stealth(aware) helps you to visualize the network traffic and the Nodes in your computing environment. (Nodes are any devices or user identities included in your network.) To use Stealth(aware), you install the Stealth(aware) software on one system in your environment, and you install the Stealth Discovery Agent on selected Windows and Linux systems. Installing this software is not disruptive and can be performed at any time.
The Stealth Discovery Agent collects network traffic data that enables you to identify the Nodes in your environment and their communication paths.

note.para: The Stealth Discovery Agent only captures 5-tuple values (source IPv4 address and port number, destination IPv4 address and port number, and the protocol in use).

section.para: You are then directed to import the network traffic data into Stealth(aware), and this is used to build a Stealth(aware) Model, which is a visual representation of your network. Based on the affinity level you select, you can see traffic flows and Nodes that have connections to one another in Stealth(aware).

Based on the network traffic data, Nodes are classified based on their role in the environment using a known set of characteristics. For example, Nodes can be identified as Database Servers, Web Servers, Application Servers, or Workstations based on the known differences in the way those applications communicate. After the network topology map is created, you can interact with the map to refine the model. Stealth(aware) can display up to 4,000 nodes and 8,000 traffic flow channels.

Stealth(aware) uses the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) Allocation Guidelines for TCP and UDP port number assignments for classification. If your environment does not use the standard IANA port assignments, you have the flexibility to manually reclassify the Nodes based on their function in your environment. For example, you should reclassify your Database Server Nodes if they do not use the standard IANA port assignments for Database Servers.

When the map has been configured for your environment, you can click the Deploy button. Clicking Deploy translates the Stealth(aware) Model and creates the appropriate components to be imported into Stealth Enterprise Manager, including Stealth Communities of Interest (COIs), roles, users, groups, and filters. It creates the endpoint software packages that you can install on your Nodes to Stealth enable your environment. This ensures that each Stealth endpoint (Node running Stealth endpoint software) communicates securely with other endpoints as determined by the Stealth(aware) Model you create using Stealth(aware).

formalpara.title: Stealth(aware) Model Objects
formalpara.para:
The Stealth(aware) Model can include the following objects:
Solution – A Solution is an application stack; for example, an order processing, ERP, or HR application.
The Stealth(aware) Affinitization and auto modeling process identifies those devices and user identities (Nodes) in the network that have frequent communications with each other, and are therefore likely to represent a single application stack. A Solution is comprised of Profiles and their connecting Channels.
Profile – A Profile is a container for devices that perform a similar function; for example, Web Servers, Application Servers, and Database Servers. Profiles are defined on the Stealth(aware) Map through the automated Affinitization of the network traffic flows recorded during Stealth Discovery and using the auto modeling process.
Affinitization identifies those devices that include similar traffic flows to other devices, which enables Stealth(aware) to create Profiles that combine similar devices into a single object. During the process of creating Profiles, individual devices (for example, Web Servers) are also auto-classified using a heuristics analysis of the traffic data to and from each device.
That is, affinitization helps simplify the modeling process by combining similar devices together and representing them as a single object on the map.
Channel – A Channel contains the set of individual device traffic flows either between Profiles (External Channels) or among members of the same Profile (Internal Channels).
Each traffic flow is defined by the source and destination of the IPv4 address and port, by the direction of the traffic, as well as by the TCP or UDP communications protocol.
Communication Policies can be set for Channels on individual Profiles or traffic flows while building the Stealth(aware) Model.
Node – A Node is any device or user identity in the computing environment.
When Affinitization is set to Off, Nodes appear on the map. When Affinitization is set to Low, Medium, or High, Nodes with the same classification are affinitized into Profiles, with Channels drawn between each of the Profiles containing the Nodes.
In this release, each discovered IP address is displayed as an individual Node. (For systems that include multiple NICs with different IP addresses, each individual NIC is displayed as its own Node.)
If the name of a Solution, Profile, or Node is too long, it will be appear concatenated on the map.

formalpara.title: Standard Solutions
formalpara.para:
The top of the map displays the following standard solutions that are automatically created and always displayed on the map. After the Auto Modeling process finishes, the following Solutions are populated:
Intranet Solution – A Solution that contains Profiles (and their Nodes) that were not added to an existing Solution during the Auto Modeling process. This includes Profiles that are classified as Workstations.
The address space (that is, the range of IP addresses in the private range) is predefined and cannot be modified.
Infrastructure Solution – A Solution to which you add Profiles (and their Nodes) that were not added to an existing Solution during the Auto Modeling process. You should drag-and-drop Profiles for infrastructure servers (such as DNS, AD, Domain Controllers, and routers) that will never be Stealth-enabled into this Solution.
Enterprise Manager Solution – A Solution that contains the Profile for the Management Server. The Management Server Profile is the root of the Enterprise Manager Solution. If you classify a Profile as a Management Server, you can manually drag-and-drop this Profile into the Enterprise Manager Solution.
Internet Solution – A Solution that contains Profiles (and their Nodes) that were not added to an existing Solution during the Auto Modeling process. This Solution contains Profiles that will never be Stealth-enabled.
The address space in the public range is predefined and cannot be modified.

formalpara.title: Model Details
formalpara.para:
In a Stealth(aware) Model, a Profile Chain defines the relationship between service providers and service consumers. Each consumer of the network traffic data is located below the provider of that service. The Create Solutions tool is used to define Profiles as the basis, or root, to create a Solution. The default root is Database Profiles. Each vertical stack of Profile Chains begins at the Database Server (by default) and ends at the Mixed Profile (if it exists). In a Solution, Profiles are arranged based on the classification order as follows:
Database Server
Database Proxy
Application Server
Application Proxy
Web Server
Web Proxy
Admin Users
Admin Workstations
Users (non-admin)
Workstations (non-admin)
Mixed

section.para: Profiles include Nodes and Internal or External Channels that encompasses all members of the Profile.

Channels are the lines on the map that connect Profiles containing Nodes to one another. If Channels connect two Profiles that are Stealth-enabled, you can apply Stealth policies to flows within the Channel. Those Channels are a composite of all of the traffic flows that have been observed between those two objects.

Note the following:
Any Profiles that are classified as Workstations (even Workstations that were previously in the Profile Chains), but are not yet Stealth-enabled, are automatically moved into the Intranet Solution during the auto modeling process.
This includes the Profiles that Stealth(aware) has classified as Workstations or that you have manually classified as Workstations.
Any Profiles that are classified as Users—whether classified by Stealth(aware) or manually classified by you—remain at the bottom of the model. These profiles can be manually Stealth-enabled.
If you want to deploy these Profiles, you must manually drag-and-drop a new Solution onto the map using the Add Objects tool, and then move those Profiles into that Solution. It is recommended that you name that Solution “Stealth Users.”
Any profiles that are not modeled into Solutions are added to the Intranet or Internet Solutions, based on the IP addresses of the Nodes in the Profile. If the Profile contains Nodes that fall into both ranges of IP addresses (Internet and Intranet), the Profile are divided and moved into the appropriate solution.
Clicking on a Solution expands the Solution to display the Profiles and their connecting Channels within that Solution. Profiles that have a blue background are designated to be Stealth-enabled.

After using the Create Solutions tool, each new Solution contains the Profiles that were modeled into each Solution. The user can manually select the profiles used as roots, or the Stealth(aware) algorithms can automatically select them for the user.

section.title: Mapping Stealth(aware) Objects to Stealth(core)
section.para:
The following information describes how Stealth(aware) objects map to objects in Stealth(core):
A Stealth(aware) Project maps to a Stealth(core) configuration that includes a Service role.
A Stealth(aware) Solution maps to a set of Stealth(core) roles, COIs, and filters that are a subset of the configuration.
A Stealth(aware) Profile maps to a Stealth(core) role.
A Stealth(aware) Channel maps to Stealth(core) COIs and filters between roles, where the filters are defined based on the Stealth(aware) policies that are configured for the flows in the Channel.

section.title: Supported Characters and Length Restrictions in Enterprise Manager and Stealth(aware)
section.para:
When you are creating components in Enterprise Manager and Stealth(aware)—including configuration, COI, role, and endpoint software file names, as well as user IDs—you must use supported characters and meet the length restrictions.
The first character in a name must be a letter, and only supported characters can be used. The only exceptions are as follows:
User IDs can begin with a letter, number, or underscore (_).
User Names and Group Names can begin with any character and can include any character (that is supported by Microsoft).

The following characters are supported:
Upper and lowercase letters
Numbers (0-9)
Space ( )
A space cannot be the first character or last character in a name.
Underscore (_)
Hyphen (-)
Comma (,)
Period (.)
Multiple periods in a row are not supported.
Exclamation point (!)
Dollar sign ($)
Percent sign (%)
Ampersand (&)
Single quotation mark (‘)
Grave accent (`)
Parentheses ( )
Equal sign (=)
At sign (@)
Square brackets ([ ])
Caret (^)
Curly brackets ({ })
Tilde (~)
Colon (:) is supported in IPv6 addresses only. You cannot use a colon in a component name.
In addition, COI names and filter set names must be 28 characters or fewer.

note.para: COI and filter names are generated automatically in Stealth(aware) to meet these requirements.

section.title: Updating the Project Name and Details (Project Details Panel)
section.para:
Use the Project Details panel to update the Project name and details, as follows:
In the upper-left corner of the map, click the Project name, for example, Untitled 1.
The Project Details panel appears.
In the Project Name field, enter a new name for the project.
The default name is Untitled x, where x is a generated number.
The new name can include any characters that are supported by Microsoft and can be a maximum length of 45 characters.
Enter a unique name for each new project you create.
For DNS Resolution, if you want the DNS servers that are configured on the system running Stealth(aware) to attempt to resolve the host name associated with each Node, leave the default value as On. This process runs continuously and automatically to attempt to resolve host names as new Nodes are added to Stealth(aware) and to confirm that existing host names are correct. Host names are displayed on the Node Details panel and on the Profile Details panel (only if a custom Node Name has not been entered).
If you do not want the DNS Servers to attempt to resolve host names, select Off.
In the Description field, enter a description of your project that you can use to help you identify it (up to 255 characters).
Under Enforcement, leave the default value or select a new enforcement level from the list.
Alternatively, you can set this value when you deploy the project, as described in .
This setting provides a guideline for the filters that are created by Stealth(aware); however, filtering is also dependent on Channel policies and whether or not the connection uses clear text.
Select one of the following:
Enforce IP Addresses and Services – Filters are generated to enforce IP addresses and both local and remote ports.
Enforce IP Addresses – Filters are generated to enforce local ports on the providing services and IP addresses on the consuming Profiles.
Enforce Services – Filters are generated to enforce local ports on the services.
Don’t enforce either IP Addresses or Services – Filters are only generated when they are required.
Click Save Project.
The project is saved on the local system. The Project Details panel closes, and the updated project name appears on the upper-left corner of the map.

Note that the Project Details pane also includes the following:
Created – The date and time that the Project was created in local system time.
Last Updated – The date and time that the Project was last updated.

chapter.title: Importing Existing Data and Installing the Discovery Agent on Nodes
chapter.para: This section describes how to optionally import existing network traffic data in packet capture (pcap or cap) format, and then install the Stealth Discovery Agent on Nodes.

section.title: Initial Discovery Guidelines
section.para: You should use an existing Network Map to identify optimal capture points that can be used to acquire network traffic information in packet capture (pcap or cap) format. The Network Map should include the following information about the datacenter:

listitem.para: Application characteristics and security requirements
IP addresses (identifying which IP addresses are private and non-routable, and which are public but are used in the data center)
Private IP address ranges include:
Ports
Host names
Roles
Existing segmentation (firewalls, VLANs, switch infrastructure, and network segments)

section.para: Optimal capture points are the systems that make up the center of activity for your solution or datacenter. These might include database servers or the key components and tiers of the application stack.

note.para: It is recommended that you limit the size of each file you import to less than 30 MB to minimize the amount of time required to import data to Stealth(aware).
You can either limit the time you spend capturing data, or you can divide one large file into multiple smaller files using a program like Wireshark editcap.

section.title: Optionally Importing Existing Network Traffic Data
section.para: Before installing the Discovery Agent on any Nodes, you can use standard network analyzer tools (such as Wireshark and tcpdump) to create your Network Map and collect network traffic data in packet capture (pcap or cap) format. For example, you can configure most switches or routers to generate network traffic data. This initial information can help you understand where in your network you should install the Discovery Agent, which in turn can help you identify those Nodes on which you want to install the Stealth endpoint software.

note.para: If you use another format besides pcap or cap to collect your traffic data, you might be able to convert it to pcap format using a tool such as Wireshark.

section.para: Best Practice: It can take some time to complete the process of importing network traffic data. provides guidelines on network traffic data file processing time. To start working with the traffic data in Stealth(aware) more quickly, it is a best practice to copy a smaller amount of traffic data or a limited number of traffic data files to import at one time. It is recommended that you limit pcap each pcap file you import to less than 30 MB, either by limiting the time you spend capturing data, or dividing one large file into multiple smaller files using a program like Wireshark editcap. It is also recommended that you incrementally import pcap files (one at a time) and that you complete the pcap file import for each capture point before advancing to another capture point.

If you have any existing network traffic files in pcap or cap format that you want to import, do the following:
Click the Import Traffic Data tool.
The Import Traffic Data panel appears.
Click Browse to File, select a file to import, and then click Open.
Only pcap or cap files can be imported (other file types, such as pcapng and NetFlow files in NFC format are not supported).
Files are not removed from the directory when they are imported into Stealth(aware). Therefore, if you create a new project and browse to the same directory, all files that were previously imported into the old project can be imported into the new project.
The Import Traffic Data panel closes, and a Processing message appears. The file or files are imported.

If you want to refine the existing model based on the network traffic data that you just imported, see . Otherwise, perform the remaining procedures in this section to install the Discovery Agent on Nodes and then import additional network traffic data to update your Stealth(aware) Model.

section.title: Configuring a Windows File Share for the Discovery Agent Network Traffic Data Files
section.para: When you install the Discovery Agent on Nodes, you must determine which Windows file share the network traffic data files (in packet capture (pcap) format) should be sent to.

note.para: In normal operations, you do not send these network traffic data files directly to the system running Stealth(aware), because that system might not be accessible to all Nodes. However, in a Proof-of-Concept environment, you could send these network traffic data files directly to the system running Stealth(aware).

section.para: The file share must be a Common Internet File System (CIFS) file share, which is a Windows native file-sharing protocol.

If you have not already done so, use the standard Windows method to configure a Windows file share on a system to which you want to send the network traffic data (pcap) files. This file share should be accessible to the following:
The system running Stealth(aware)
The Nodes running the Discovery Agent
Best Practice: For security, configure the file share to enable write-access for the Nodes that you want to run the Discovery Agent.

section.title: Understanding Where to Install the Stealth Discovery Agent
section.para: The Stealth Discovery Agent collects additional network traffic data (in pcap format) about your environment, including information about network flows, Node types, and their properties. The Discovery Agent discovers all 5-tuple traffic that is visible from a Node’s network interfaces. (All 5-tuple traffic is captured for each network interface that is enabled and active.) When you install the Discovery Agent on a Windows or Linux Node, the Discovery Agent collects both source and destination information, which means that information about two Nodes is included in each communication flow.

You can install the Discovery Agent on as many or as few Nodes as required to provide a clear model of your environment. For example, you could limit installation of the Discovery Agent to servers in your environment. When workstations communicate with the servers running the Discovery Agent, information about those workstations is then included in the network traffic data. When the network traffic data is imported to Stealth(aware), both the server and workstation Nodes appear in the Stealth(aware) Model.

Best practice: Install the Discovery Agent on one Node in each broadcast domain in your environment. (A broadcast domain is a logical division of a computer network, in which all Nodes can reach each other by broadcast at the data link layer.) On the Node running the Discovery Agent, the NIC must be in promiscuous mode.
Install the Discovery Agent on the appropriate Nodes in your environment to meet the needs of your planned Stealth deployment.

listitem.para: Only the IP header information is captured by the Stealth Discovery Agents (not the traffic contents).
The Stealth Discovery Agent can be installed on virtual machines, and it can discover virtual machines that have unique IP addresses on the network.

section.title: Understanding How Long the Stealth Discovery Agent Should Run
section.para: Allowing the Discovery Agent to collect too much data can cause significant delays when the data is imported and analyzed; therefore, it is important to deploy the Agent strategically and for short periods of time, as follows:

listitem.para: Recommended short-term capture period values (12 hours or less)

note.para: The following are the default values when you install the Discovery Agent.

listitem.para: How often to start a capture: 840 seconds (14 minutes)
How long to capture data: 65 seconds (1 minute, 5 seconds)
How often to move files: 1,800 seconds (30 minutes)
Recommended long-term capture period values (several days)
How often to start a capture: 3,240 seconds (54 minutes)
How long to capture data: 120 seconds (2 minutes)
How often to move files: 3,600 seconds (60 minutes)

section.title: Discovery Agent Supported Operating Systems
section.para: There is one Discovery Agent for Windows and one Discovery Agent for Linux. The Discovery Agent can be installed on all systems that support Stealth(core).

The following operating systems are supported:
Windows operating systems:
Windows 7
Windows Server 2008 R2
Windows 8 and Windows 8.1
Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 R2
Windows 10
Linux operating systems:
Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) 6.x, 32-bit and 64-bit
Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) 7.x, 64-bit
SUSE Linux Enterprise Server (SLES) 11.x, 32-bit and 64-bit
SUSE Linux Enterprise Server (SLES) 12.x, 64-bit
Ubuntu 12.04 LTS, 32-bit and 64-bit
Ubuntu 14.04 LTS, 64-bit

section.title: Installing the Discovery Agent on Nodes Running Windows
section.para: You can install the Discovery Agent on a Node running one of the Windows operating systems listed in .

As part the installation process, the following software is installed on the Windows Node, if it is not already installed:
Microsoft Visual C++ 2015 Redistributable x86 or x64, depending on the system architecture
Win10Pcap

Do the following to install the Discovery Agent on Nodes running Windows:
Save the Discovery Agent executable file in a location that is accessible from your Windows Nodes. This file is named Stealth_Discovery_Installer_Release_<x64 or x86> and is included with the Stealth(aware) ISO file in the discovery\windows folder.
From Windows Explorer, right-click the Discovery Agent executable file for your system type, and then select Run as administrator.
If you are prompted to allow the program to make changes to your computer, click Yes.
On the Unisys Stealth(aware) Auto Discovery window, click Install.
If it is not already installed, wait while Microsoft Visual C++ 2015 Redistributable is installed.
If Win10Pcap is not already installed, wait while it is automatically installed.
When the installation is complete, the Unisys Stealth(aware) Auto Discovery Setup Wizard launches.
Click Next.
It is recommended that you retain the destination folder default location, and then click Next.
Enter the appropriate values on the Discovery Share Settings page, as follows:
Remote Share – Enter the network address of the share you configured in .
Remote Share User – Enter a user name that has privileges to write to this share.
Remote Share Password – Enter the password for the user.
This password cannot be updated unless you reinstall the Discovery Agent software. Therefore, you should enter credentials for a user whose password does not expire.
Click Next.
Enter the appropriate values on the Discovery Collection Settings page, as follows:
When you are asked how often (in seconds) you would like to start a capture, enter a new value or retain the default value of 840 seconds (14 minutes).
When you are asked how long (in seconds) you would like each capture to last, enter a new value or retain the default value of 65 seconds (1 minute, 5 seconds).
When you are asked how often (in seconds) you would like to move completed capture files to the remote directory, enter a new value or retain the default value of 1800 seconds (30 minutes).
The value for The length of time (in seconds) that each capture sessions lasts should be equal to or less than the value for The time interval (in seconds) that a new capture is started. If these values are the same, this means that data is continuously captured.
Click Next.
Click Install.
When the installation is complete, click Finish.
When you see a message that reads “Installation Successfully Completed,” click Close.
If the remote share, user name, and password are not correct, the installation will fail. If the installation fails, do the following:
Perform this procedure again, and verify that the Discovery Share Settings page includes the correct information.
For more information, see the Discovery.txt log file, which is located in C:\ProgramData\Unisys\Stealth.
The process of discovering data begins automatically.

If you want to stop the discovery process, do the following to stop the Unisys Stealth Discovery service:
From the Start menu, enter Services in the Search box, right-click Services, and select Run as administrator.
Locate the Unisys Stealth Discovery service in the list of Services.
Right-click the Unisys Stealth Discovery service and select Stop.

section.title: Installing the Discovery Agent on Nodes Running Linux
section.para: You can install the Discovery Agent on a Node running one of the Linux operating systems listed in .

As part of the installation process, the following software is installed on the Linux Node, if it is not already installed:
libpcap
libxml2

note.para: If you need additional information about the Discovery Agent for Linux, access the Man page by entering man nodediscoveryd or entering man nodediscoveryd-conf.

section.para:
Do the following to install the Discovery Agent on Nodes running Linux:
Log on to the system as root, and then open a terminal window.
Do the following to mount the remote file share you configured in :
Make a new directory on the system.
For example, enter the following command:mkdir /mnt/nodediscovery
Configure the mount point in /etc/fstab.
For example, to open /etc/fstab using vi, enter the following command: vi /etc/fstab
Insert a new line for the mount point using the following format: <remote file share> <local mount point> <file system type> <mount options, including user name and password, if required>
For example, insert the following new line://192.168.1.1/share /mnt/nodediscovery cifs username=user,password=pwd 0 0
Save and close the file.
Mount the file share.
For example, enter the following command:mount /mnt/nodediscovery
Save the Discovery Agent package file in a location that is accessible from your Linux Nodes. This file is named nodediscoveryd-<version>.<distribution> and is included with the Stealth(aware) ISO file in the discovery/linux folder.
An RPM file is available for Red Hat Enterprise Linux and SUSE Linux Enterprise Server, and a DEB file is available for Ubuntu.
Change to the directory where you saved the Discovery Agent package file.
Enter one of the following commands to install the software, based on your operating system:
For Red Hat Enterprise Linux, enter the following command: yum install nodediscoveryd-<version>.<distribution>.rpm
For SUSE Linux Enterprise Server, enter the following command: zypper install nodediscoveryd-<version>.<distribution>.rpm
For Ubuntu, enter the following command: dpkg –i nodediscoveryd_<version>_<distribution>.deb
On Ubuntu systems, you see an error that the job failed to start and that there were errors encountered when processing nodediscovery-d. Ignore these errors.
For Red Hat Enterprise Linux and SUSE Linux Enterprise Server, if prompted, enter Y to install the software. You see a message that instructs you to run nodedisoveryd-conf as root and follow the prompts.
Do the following to either manually configure the settings or to silently pass all parameters required for configuration:
To manually configure the settings, do the following:
For all operating systems, enter the following command to configure the software: nodediscoveryd-conf
When you are asked where you want to move capture files, enter the location of the mount point you created at the beginning of this procedure. Press Enter to retain the default value of /mnt/nodediscovery.
Alternatively, enter a new value.
When you are asked how often (in seconds) you would like to start a capture, press Enter to retain the default value of 840 seconds (14 minutes).
Alternatively, enter a new value.
When you are asked how long (in seconds) you would like each capture to last, press Enter to retain the default value of 65 seconds (1 minute, 5 seconds).
Alternatively, enter a new value.
The value for how long (in seconds) you would like each capture to last should be equal to or less than the value for how often (in seconds) you would like to start a capture. If these values are the same, this means that data is continuously captured.
When you are asked how often (in seconds) you would like to move completed capture files to the remote share, press Enter to retain the default value of 1800 seconds (30 minutes).
Alternatively, enter a new value.
To silently pass all parameters required for configuration, enter the following command: nodediscoveryd-conf –r <mount point> –s <seconds to start a capture> –l <seconds for a capture to last> –m <seconds to move capture to remote share>
Where
<mount point> is the mount point where you want to move capture files, which you entered at the beginning of this procedure (by default, /mnt/nodediscovery)
<seconds to start a capture> is how often (in seconds) you would like to start a capture, by default 840 seconds (14 minutes)
<seconds for a capture to last> is how long (in seconds) you would like a capture to last, by default 65 seconds (1 minute, 5 seconds)
<seconds to move capture to remote share> is how often (in seconds) you would like to move completed capture files to the remote share, by default 1800 seconds (30 minutes)
The value for how long (in seconds) you would like each capture to last should be equal to or less than the value for how often (in seconds) you would like to start a capture. If these values are the same, this means that data is continuously captured.
For example, enter nodediscoveryd-conf –r /mnt/nodediscovery –s 840 –l 65 –m 1800
The settings you enter become the new default values, and these values are written to /etc/nodediscoveryd/settings.xml.
Enter one of the following commands to start the Discovery service, based on your operating system:
For Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6.x and SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 11.x, enter the following command: service nodediscoveryd start
For Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.x and SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 12.x, enter the following command: systemctl start nodediscoveryd
For Ubuntu, enter the following command: apt-get install –f
The process of discovering data begins.

If you want to stop the discovery process, do the following to stop the Unisys Stealth Discovery service:
Log on to the system as root, and then open a terminal window.
Enter one of the following commands to stop the Discovery service, based on your operating system:
For Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6.x and SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 11.x, enter the following command: service nodediscoveryd stop
For Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.x and SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 12.x, enter the following command: systemctl stop nodediscoveryd
For Ubuntu, enter the following command: stop nodediscoveryd

chapter.title: Using Stealth(aware) to Create a Model
chapter.para: Use the information in this section to create a Stealth(aware) Model that can then be used to deploy your Stealth environment.
Best Practice: It is a best practice to import all packet capture data, set the affinity level, and create Solutions before you manually modify or create any Profiles or Solutions.

section.title: Importing Traffic Data (Import Traffic Data Tool)
section.para: Using the Import Traffic Data tool, you can import network traffic data from standard network analyzer tools (such as Wireshark and tcpdump) or from the Stealth Discovery Agent running on Nodes in the network.

Best Practice: It can take some time to complete the process of importing network traffic data. provides guidelines on network traffic data file processing time. To start working with the traffic data in Stealth(aware) more quickly, it is a best practice to copy a smaller amount of traffic data or a limited number of traffic data files to import at one time. It is recommended that you limit each pcap file you import to less than 30 MB, either by limiting the time you spend capturing data, or dividing one large file into multiple smaller files using a program like Wireshark editcap. It is also recommended that you incrementally import pcap files (one at a time) and that you complete the pcap file import for each capture point before advancing to another capture point.

To use the Import Traffic Data tool, do the following in Stealth(aware):
Click the Import Traffic Data tool.
The Import Traffic Data panel appears.
From the Import Traffic Data panel, do one of the following to import new pcap or cap files or select a folder that includes pcap or cap files.
Only pcap or cap files can be imported (other file types, such as pcapng and NetFlow files in NFC format are not supported).
Files are not removed from the share when they are imported into Stealth(aware). Therefore, if you create a new project and browse to the same directory, all files that were previously imported into the old project can be imported into the new project.
When you import a new file, any empty Solutions in the model are deleted. To avoid this, add at least one Profile to the empty Solution.
Click one of the following:
Click Browse to File, select a file to import, and then click Open.
Click Live Feed, browse to the file share you created in , and then click Select Folder.
If you want to continuously receive updated data from one or more Discovery Agents you installed on Nodes, ensure that the Live Feed switch is On. The Live Feed automatically imports new pcap or cap files when they appear in the directory you have selected.
The Import Traffic Data panel closes, and a Processing message appears. The file or files are imported.

The Nodes are automatically classified and affinitized based on the affinity level set for the open project, as described in . The Processing message disappears when the data import process has been successfully completed.

You can import additional pcap or cap files to improve the information in the Stealth(aware) Model, and there is no limit to the number of files you can import. In addition, you can continuously update the model with new information from the Live Feed.

caution.para: Before updating the Stealth(aware) Model, ensure Live Feed is Off.

section.title: Setting the Affinity Level (Set Affinity Level Tool)
section.para: After you import traffic data, you can use the Set Affinity Level tool to set the threshold for grouping similar Nodes into Profiles.

Using the Set Affinity Level tool, select the affinity level that most closely aligns with your Network Map. The default value is Medium.
If Nodes have very little in common, changing the Affinity Level will have little or no effect on the map.

To change the Affinity Level, do the following:
Click the Set Affinity Level tool.
The Set Affinity Level panel appears.
From the Set Affinity Level panel, select one of the following:
Low – Profiles are created with a larger number of Nodes that are less closely related to one another and that are providing and consuming some of the same services.
Medium – This is the default value. A number of Profiles between the Low and High value are created, and they are providing and consuming many of the same services.
High – Profiles are created with a smaller number of Nodes that are more closely related to one another and that are providing and consuming almost all of the same services.
Off – All Profiles are removed from the map, and you see the Nodes and their underlying relationships to one another.
If you set the Affinity Level to Off, you cannot use any of the other tools (for example, Import Traffic Data or Deploy).
When prompted, click Yes, Change.
The Processing message appears, and then closes when processing is complete.
If you change the Affinity Level, any empty Solutions in the model are deleted. To avoid this, add at least one Profile to the empty Solution.

Affinitization ignores Profiles and Solutions that you manually modified or created. You can manually create a Profile or Solution using the Add Objects tool, as described in . You can manually modify a Profile or Solution by updating the name of the Profile or Solution from the Details panel. Additionally, you can manually modify a Solution by dragging and dropping a Profile into that Solution.

There is no way to see if an existing Profile or Solution has been manually modified or created. You should make a note of any Profiles or Solutions that you manually modify or create. Stealth(aware) does not inform you of Profiles and Solutions that have been ignored by Affinitization or auto modeling.
When you import new traffic data, new Nodes are affinitized into existing Profiles and Solutions on the map.

section.title: Manually Creating Objects (Add Objects Tool)
section.para: The Add Objects tool enables you to manually add a new Solution or Profile to the map. This is an optional procedure.

note.para: If you set the Affinity Level to Off, you cannot use this tool.

section.para:
To use the Add Objects tool, do the following:
Click the Add Objects tool.
The Add Objects panel appears.
From the Add Objects panel, drag a Solution or Profile and drop it onto the map.
Enter a unique name for each Solution or Profile. This name can be a maximum length of 45 characters and must meet the requirements that are described in .
Optionally configure the following additional values for Solutions or Profiles. (You can configure these values at a later time, if you choose.)
For new Solutions, optionally add Profiles to the Solution and set the Stealth Enabled value. See for more information.
If you change the Affinity Level, any empty Solutions in the model are deleted. To avoid this, add at least one Profile to the empty Solution.
For new Profiles, optionally configure the Group Name and set the Stealth Enabled value. See for more information.
Repeat the previous steps to add as many Solutions and Profiles to the map as required.
When you are done adding new Solutions or Profiles, click the X in the corner to close the Add Objects panel.
Manually sort the new Solution or Profile you created.
For more information about Solutions, Profiles, Channels, and the Stealth(aware) Model, see .

section.title: Defining Roots for Solutions (Create Solutions Tool)
section.para: The Create Solutions tool enables you to select the Profiles to be used as the basis—or root—of Solutions. A new Solution is created for every root selected.

For example, if you choose Automated—which automatically selects all Profiles classified as Database Servers to be used as roots—and if your Model includes seven Database Server Profiles, then seven Solutions are created.

note.para: If you set the Affinity Level to Off, you cannot use this tool.

formalpara.title: Classifying and Organizing Profiles and Nodes
formalpara.para: Before you begin using the Create Solutions tool, you should ensure that your Profiles and Nodes have been classified appropriately by Stealth(aware). Classification plays an important part in modeling. Nodes are classified based on their role in the environment using a known set of characteristics. For example, Nodes can be identified as Database Servers, Web Servers, Application Servers, or Workstations based on the known differences in the way applications running on Nodes communicate. Profiles are classified based on the Nodes that they include.

section.para: Stealth(aware) uses the IANA Allocation Guidelines for TCP and UDP port number assignments for classification. If your environment does not use the standard IANA port assignments, you have the flexibility to manually reclassify the Nodes based on their function in your environment. For example, you should reclassify your Database Server Nodes if they do not use the standard IANA port assignments for Database Servers.

You can change the classification assigned by Stealth(aware) by doing the following:
Select a Profile whose classification you want to change, or that includes a Node whose classification you want to change.
In the Profile Details panel, do one of the following:
If you want to change the Profile classification, select a new classification from the list at the top of the Profile Details panel.
See for more information.
If you want to change a Node’s classification, select that Node from the Nodes list, and then update the Node classification using the list at the top of the Node Details panel.
See for more information.

If all of the Nodes in a Profile have the same classification, the Profile will have the same classification as the Nodes. If Nodes in the same Profile have different classifications, the Profile uses the Mixed classification. However, you can manually update the Profile classification as required.

In addition, from the Profile Details panel, you can move Nodes into and out of Profiles. Each discovered IP address is displayed as an individual Node. (For systems that include multiple NICs with different IP addresses, each individual NIC is displayed as its own Node.) Therefore, you might want to combine these Nodes into one Profile, if they are not already grouped.

formalpara.title: Using the Create Solutions Tool
formalpara.para:
Modeling uses the consumer and provider relationships of the Profiles to create Solutions. To model your environment using the Create Solutions tool, do the following:
Click the Create Solutions tool.
The Create Solutions panel appears.
From the Create Solutions panel, under Rooting method, select one of the following:
Automated (recommended) – Automatically creates Solutions based on all Profiles that are classified as Database Servers.
If you select Automated but no Profiles have been classified as Database Servers, then no Solutions will be created.
Manual – Enables you to manually select Profiles that you want to use as the root of your Solutions, either because no Database Servers have been identified or because you want to select Profiles manually.
Under Profile Roots (used to create Solutions), do the following based on whether you selected Automated or Manual:
If you selected Automated, review the list of Database Server Profiles, which are automatically used as the root of your Solutions.
The Database Server Profiles are also highlighted on the Stealth(aware) map.
If you selected Manual, select the Profiles you want to use from the map.
The Profiles you select are also highlighted on the Stealth(aware) map.
If you select Manual, it is a best practice to select Profiles that are classified as either Database Servers, Application Servers, or Web Servers as roots in order to generate stable Solutions. Selecting these types of servers as roots increases the likelihood that the Solutions will not require manual changes before deployment.
You can remove a Profile from the list by clicking the X associated with the Profile, or you can remove all Profiles by clicking Clear All Profiles.
If you selected Automated, under Automatically create new Solutions, determine the setting you want to use, as follows.
This setting does not appear if you selected Manual.
If you set this value to Off, when new traffic data is imported, no changes are made to existing Solutions, and new Solutions are not automatically created. (However, new Nodes are affinitized into existing Profiles and Solutions on the map. See for more information on affinitization.)
The Automatically create new Solutions function is Off by default.
If you set this value to On and import new traffic data, any new Profiles classified as Database Server are automatically used to create Solutions, and any profiles that Stealth(aware) has not moved into existing Solutions are automatically moved into the Internet or Intranet Solutions. (You do not see Profiles on the map before they are added to a Solution, unless they are classified as User Profiles.)
If you set this value to On, any empty Solutions in the model are deleted. To avoid this, add at least one Profile to the empty Solution.
In addition, any Profiles and Solutions that you manually modified or created are ignored. For example, if you turn Automatically create new Solutions on, it will not do the following:
Move a Profile into a Solution that you modified or created
Move a Profile out of a Solution that you modified or created
Delete a Solution that you modified or created (if it includes any Profiles)
Click Proceed.

section.para: Profiles that are related to the Solutions you selected as roots are sorted into Solutions based on the roots you selected. Any remaining Profiles are automatically moved into the Internet or Intranet Solutions.

section.title: Modifying Solution Details (Solution Details Panel)
section.para: Use the Solution Details panel to view (and modify, if necessary) details for a specific Solution, including the Solution name and the Profiles within the Solution.

formalpara.title: Viewing and Modifying a Solution
formalpara.para:
To view the Solution Details panel and modify the details of a Solution, do the following:
From the map, select a Solution. A Solution has a blue background if it is Stealth-enabled and a white background if it is not Stealth-enabled.
The Solution expands (if it was not already expanded), and the Solution Details panel appears.
If necessary, in the Solution Name field, modify the name of the Solution. This name can be a maximum length of 28 characters and must meet the requirements that are described in .
You cannot change the names of the Standard Solutions (Enterprise Manager, Infrastructure, Internet, and Intranet).
Review the list of Profiles in the Profiles list.
If you want to view the details of a Profile, click the Profile name. See for more information.
If you want to remove a Profile from the Solution, drag-and-drop the Profile onto the map.
The Channels field appears below the Profiles field and specifies the number of Inter-Solution Channels (that is, channels which both originate and terminate within the Solution). You cannot modify or expand the Channels field. To view the details about a Channel, click the Channel on the map.
If necessary, change the Stealth Enabled Added Profiles setting, which is the default setting for the Solution and its associated Profiles and Nodes. Stealth Enabled Added Profiles is set to On for all newly created Solutions.
If you change this value, you change the default setting for the Solution. However, you can override this setting for individual Profiles within the Solution. (For example, you might have a Solution with Stealth Enabled Added Profiles set to On that includes multiple Stealth-enabled Profiles and one non-Stealth-enabled Profile.)
Note the following:
If Stealth Enabled Added Profiles is set to On and you add a non-Stealth-enabled Profile to the Solution, that Profile will automatically become Stealth enabled.
If Stealth Enabled Added Profiles is set to Off and you add a Stealth-enabled Profile, that Profile will remain Stealth-enabled. This is because the default value for Profiles is non-Stealth-enabled, and you must have previously changed the Profile to Stealth Enabled; therefore, the value will not change automatically.
Click the X in the upper-right corner to close the Solution Details panel.
When you make a change to the Solution Details panel, the change is automatically saved.

formalpara.title: Deleting a Solution
formalpara.para:
To delete a Solution, do the following:
Select the Menu icon in the upper-right corner of the Solution Details panel.
Click Delete Solution.
When prompted, click Yes, Delete.

section.para: If the Solution you are deleting includes any Profiles, those Profiles are returned to the map.

section.title: Modifying Profile Details (Profile Details Panel)
section.para: Use the Profile Details panel to view (and modify, if necessary) details for a specific Profile, including the classification of the Profile, the Profile name, and default policies, as described in the following procedure.

formalpara.title: Viewing and Modifying a Profile
formalpara.para:
To view the Profile Details panel and modify details of a Profile, do the following:
Select a Profile directly from the map, or select a Profile by first selecting a Solution and then selecting a Profile from the expanded Solution or from the Solution Details panel.
A Profile has a blue background if it is Stealth-enabled and a white background if it is not Stealth-enabled.
The Profile Details panel appears.
If necessary, click the classification icon at the top of the panel and select a new classification from the list.
The classification of the Profile is based on the classification of all of the Nodes included in the Profile.
The following table provides a description of each classification.
If the classification icon is a question mark (?), the Profile is unclassified, either because it could not be automatically classified or because you created it manually using the Add Objects tool. If you select a classification for an unclassified Profile, you cannot change the Profile back to unclassified.
Stealth(aware) does not automatically classify any Profiles as Admin Users. You can manually classify Profiles as Admin Users, as required.
Profile Classifications
Icon Description
Database Proxy
Database Server
Web Proxy
Web Server
Admin User
Application Server
Application Proxy
Admin Workstation
Workstation
Users
Mixed
This indicates that Nodes of different classifications are included in the same Profile.
The Stealth Management Server, Stealth Standalone Authorization Server, and Stealth Service Mode classifications also appear in this list. Ignore these classifications; they are not supported in this release.
If necessary, in the Profile Name field, modify the name of the Profile. This name can be a maximum length of 45 characters and must meet the requirements in .
If necessary, click the policy icon to the right of the Profile Name field and select a new policy from the list to change the Inter-Profile Policy, which sets the default for all traffic flows that connect to this Profile.
The Inter-Profile Policy is only visible when the Stealth Enabled setting is set to On.
The following table provides a description of each policy:
Policies
Icon Description
Stealth Allow – Allow Stealth traffic.
Clear Text Allow – Allow clear text traffic.
Block Clear Text and Stealth – Block clear text and Stealth traffic.
In the Group Name field, specify the name of the Active Directory group that the Profile is associated with. (That is the name of the Active Directory group in which the users of the member Nodes are included.) This name can be a maximum length of 45 characters and must meet the requirements that are described in .
Entering information in this field is required so that your endpoints can be authorized. This becomes the Active Directory Group that identifies your Stealth endpoint users.
If you have not already done so, use your Active Directory server to create a group and then configure users to be members of that Active Directory group. For example, if you are configuring a Database Server Profile, and if your Database Server users are located in an Active Directory group named DB_Server_Admins, then you would enter DB_Server_Admins in the Group Name field in Stealth(aware).
If the Profile is part of a Solution, you see the Solution field under the Group Name field. If necessary, you can click the name of the parent Solution to access the Solution Details panel. See for more information. (If the Profile is not part of a Solution, you do not see the Solution field.)
Use the Stealth Enabled switch to determine if the Profile should be Stealth-enabled by selecting one of the following:
On – The Profile will be Stealth-enabled. The background color of the Profile is blue.
Off – The Profile will not be Stealth-enabled. The background color of the Profile is white.
Be very careful when changing the Stealth Enabled setting. If you turn this setting to Off and deploy the associated Solution, the Profile and its Nodes will not be Stealth enabled. Even if you install the Stealth endpoint software on an associated Node, that Node will not be able to use Stealth communications if Stealth is not enabled on its Profile.
If you set the Stealth Enabled switch to On, you should ensure that the Policy is set to Stealth Allow.
By default, the Profile is set to Stealth-enabled or not Stealth-enabled based on whether the Solution switch Stealth Enabled Added Profiles is set to On or Off. However, if you modify the Profile before adding it to a Solution, the Profile will not use the default Stealth value of the Solution.
If necessary, from the Nodes list, do the following:
To remove a Node from the Profile, drag-and-drop the Node onto the map. The Node is moved onto the map into a new Profile, where it is the only member.
To view or update details for a member Node using the Node Details panel, click a Node from the list. Nodes are listed by IP address, host name, or name (depending on what values are defined).
If the Profile includes an Internal Channel, you can review the flows and if necessary, update the policy on each flow, as follows:
If the Profile is Stealth enabled, set a Stealth policy, either Stealth Allow or Block Clear Text and Stealth.
Although you can set Clear Text Allow as an option, this is not recommended for traffic flows that connect two Stealth-enabled Profiles.
If the Profile is not Stealth enabled, the Clear Text Allow policy is set by default and cannot be changed, but no policy is visible.
Click the X in the upper-right corner to close the Profile Details panel.
When you make a change to the Profile Details panel, the change is automatically saved.

formalpara.title: Deleting a Profile
formalpara.para:
To delete a Profile, do the following:
Select the Menu icon in the upper-right corner of the Profile Details panel.
Click Delete Profile.
When prompted, click Yes, Delete.

section.para: If the Profile you are deleting includes any Nodes, those Nodes are each returned to the map in a new Profile.

formalpara.title: Viewing External Channels for the Profile
formalpara.para: To view details of the External Channels for this Profile, click the line going from the selected Profile to a different Profile or a Solution.

section.title: Modifying Node Details (Node Details Panel)
section.para: Use the Node Details panel to view (and modify, if necessary) details for a specific Node, including the classification of the Node and the Node name.

To view the Node Details panel and modify details of a Node, do the following:
Select a Profile, and then click a Node under the Nodes heading.
You might need to expand the Nodes list to see all Nodes that are members of the Profile.
The Node Details panel appears.
If necessary, click the classification icon at the top-center of the panel and select a new classification from the menu. The following table provides a description of each classification.
If the classification icon is a question mark (?), the Node is unclassified. If you select a classification for an unclassified Node, you cannot change the Node back to unclassified.
Stealth(aware) does not automatically classify any Nodes as Admin Users. You can manually classify Nodes as Admin Users, as required.
Node Classifications
Icon Description
Database Proxy
Database Server
Web Proxy
Web Server
Admin User
Application Server
Admin Workstation
Workstation
User
The Stealth Management Server, Stealth Standalone Authorization Server, and Stealth Service Mode classifications also appear in this list. Ignore these classifications; they are not supported in this release.
If necessary, in the Node Name field, modify the name of the Node. If the Node is running the Discovery Agent or if the DNS Resolution is set to On in the Project Details panel, the Node Name field is set to the Node host name by default.
If the Node is not running the Discovery Agent, or if the DNS Resolution is set to Off, or if DNS Resolution is Set to On but the host name cannot be resolved, the Node Name field is set to the Node IP address by default.
If you want to change the name, it can be a maximum length of 45 characters and must meet the requirements in .

The following additional information appears on the Node Details panel, which cannot be changed. You can review the following settings:
The Host Name field, includes the Node host name, if the host name is known. If the host name is not known, this field is blank.
The IP Address field includes the Node IP address.
The Parent field includes the name of the Profile that the Node is included in. If you want to view the details of the parent Profile, click the Profile name. See for more information.
The icon next to the Profile name indicates the Profile classification.
The Flows diagram provides a visual representation of the Channels (and their associated flows) between the current Node and all other Nodes with which it communicates, and includes the following information:
The classification and name of the current node.
For each flow, either the name of the IANA service or the word Unassigned, a colon, and then the protocol and port.
If the ports and protocols are not listed on the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) registry, they are prefaced by Unassigned. (This includes ports and protocols used by Stealth.)
One of the following policies is shown on each flow:
Stealth Allow
Clear Text Allow
Block Clear Text and Stealth
See for more information.
Information about the other Node (with which the selected Node is communicating), including:
The IP address, host name, or name of the other Node
The classification of the other Node
Whether the other Node is providing services to the current Node (the arrow above the classification is pointed up), or the other Node is consuming services from the current Node (the arrow above the classification is pointed down)
To access the Node Details panel of the other Node, you can click its IP address, host name, or name (depending on what values are defined for the other Node).
Click the X in the upper-right corner or click anywhere on the map to close the Node Details panel.

note.para: When you make a change to the Node Details panel, the change is automatically saved.

section.title: Modifying Channel Details (Channel Details Panel)
section.para: Use the Channel Details panel to view details about the set of individual device traffic flows between Profiles (External Channels).

Each Channel on the Channel Details panel consists of the following:
A Profile or Node at the top (the provider of services) and a Profile or Node at the bottom (the consumer of services)
Traffic flows that are defined by either the name of the IANA service or the word Unassigned, a colon, and then the protocol and port that is used to listen to incoming data or requests

note.para: If the ports and protocols are not listed on the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) registry, they are prefaced by Unassigned. (This includes ports and protocols used by Stealth.)

section.para:
To view the Channel Details panel and modify details of a Channel, do the following:
From the map, select a Channel.
A blue shadow appears behind the Channel and the Channel Details panel appears.
If necessary, modify the policy associated with a traffic flow by clicking the policy icon and selecting a policy from the menu, as follows.
On a traffic flow that connects to two non-Stealth-enabled Profiles, the Clear Text Allow policy is set by default, it cannot be changed, and the policy is not visible.
On a traffic flow that connects two Stealth-enabled Profiles, set a Stealth policy: either Stealth Allow or Block Clear Text and Stealth.
Although you can set Clear Text Allow as an option, this is not recommended for traffic flows that connect two Stealth-enabled Profiles.
On a traffic flow that connects to one non-Stealth-enabled Profile, set a Clear Text policy: either Clear Text Allow or Block Clear Text and Stealth.
Click the X in the upper-right corner to close the Channel Details panel.

section.title: Moving Nodes Between Profiles and Moving Profiles Between Solutions

formalpara.title: Moving Nodes Between Profiles
formalpara.para: If Affinitization is set to High, Medium, or Low, each Node is included in a Profile on the map. To remove a Node from a Profile, use the Profile Details panel for the Profile that the Node is included in. From the Profile Details panel, from the Nodes list, drag-and-drop the Node onto the map. The Node is then included in a new Profile. For more information, see .

section.para: To move a Node into a new Profile, drag the Profile that includes the Node on top of another Profile to combine the Profiles and member Nodes into one Profile, and then click Yes, Continue. The Profile that you drag is merged into the Profile on which you drop it, which means that the “dragged” Profile takes on the settings, policies, and name of the other Profile.

When you add or remove Nodes from Profiles, the classification of the Profile might be automatically updated. For example, if you add a Node classified as a Workstation to a Profile that originally included only Nodes classified as Databases, that Profile classification would change from Database to Mixed. If you then removed the Node classified as a Workstation, the Profile would return to being classified as Database.

formalpara.title: Moving Profiles Between Solutions
formalpara.para: On the map, you can drag Profiles into closed Solutions or into expanded Solutions. In addition, you can remove a Profile from a Solution by expanding the Solution and dragging out the Profile, or by using the Solution Details panel for the Solution that the Profile belongs to. From the Solution Details panel, from the Profiles list, drag-and-drop the Profile it onto the map. For more information, see .

section.title: Verifying That Your Solutions Are Ready for Deployment
section.para: If your Solutions are not ready for deployment and you need to make changes, do so now. When your Solutions are configured for your environment, proceed to . (Configured Solutions include Profiles that have Group names and appropriate Stealth policies configured for each Profile and appropriate Stealth policies configured for each Channel.)
You will use the information in to initially configure the Stealth(core) environment, and then you will return to Stealth(aware) to deploy your Solutions.

chapter.title: Initially Configuring the Stealth(core) Environment for Stealth(aware)
chapter.para: Before you can deploy Stealth(aware), you must initially configure the Management Server in your Stealth(core) environment.
This section describes a minimal configuration that enables you install and configure the Management Server so that you can deploy your Solutions from Stealth(aware).

note.para: For more detailed information on configuring Stealth(core), see the Unisys Stealth Solution Information Center.

section.title: Management Server Requirements
section.para: Before you install the Enterprise Manager software, you must meet the following requirements and configure the following required settings on the system you want to act as the Stealth Management Server.

section.title: System and ISO Requirements
section.para: You can install the Management Server software on the same system that you used to install Stealth(aware), as long as that system meets the requirements for the Management Server software. Alternatively, you can install the Management Server software on a separate system in your environment.

The Management Server software can be installed on a virtual machine or a physical server. The following are the system requirements:
The software must be installed on a server that is dedicated to running the Management Server software and, optionally, Stealth(aware). The server should not be used for any other purpose in the datacenter.
The Management Server must run Windows Server 2012 R2 x64 (any version).
Be sure to configure Server with a GUI mode. See https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh831786(v=ws.11).aspx for more information.
Apply all available cumulative and security updates provided for your Microsoft operating system.
The Management Server host name must not include an underscore. (All other Windows special characters are supported.)
The Management Server must have a static IPv4 address.
The Management Server must meet the following hardware requirements: Management Server Hardware Requirements
Memory Multicore Processor Disk Space
6 GB or greater
3-4 cores (minimum)
Adding additional processor cores can increase your ability to handle multiple authorization functions simultaneously.
30 GB

In addition, ensure that you have the Unisys Stealth Solution Release ISO file, which contains the software required for the Management Server installation. You can download this file as directed in the Welcome Letter you receive from Unisys. Save the ISO file on the system you want to act as the Management Server.

section.title: Domain Participation
section.para: It is a requirement for the Management Server to be part of a domain; make sure that it is part of the appropriate domain before proceeding. Your endpoint users must be included in Active Directory groups in order to be authorized. This means that the Management Server must belong to an Active Directory domain. In addition, the Active Directory server must either be Stealth-enabled, or the Management Server and endpoints must include clear text filters to the Active Directory server. (For endpoint authorization, local users and Active Directory users are not supported for this release; only Active Directory groups are supported.)

caution.para: It is critical that you determine what resources are required for Stealth endpoints (including the Management Server) to function within the domain, and identify whether those resources should be Stealth-enabled or clear text. For example, if your Domain Controller, Active Directory, and Domain Name System (DNS) servers are not Stealth-enabled, you must assign a filter to roles so that the Stealth endpoints can communicate in clear text to those servers. If your Domain Controller, Active Directory, and DNS servers are Stealth-enabled, they must share a Service COI and a workgroup COI with the roles they authorize.
Information about creating filters or Stealth-enabling servers is available later in this document.

section.title: Domain Name Resolution
section.para: The Management Server computer name must be able to be resolved by a DNS server or other name resolution mechanism. If the Management Server is in a domain, the shortcut created to launch Enterprise Manager uses the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) of the Management Server, and therefore the FQDN must be resolvable.
If the computer name is not resolvable, you might have to manually update the Enterprise Manager shortcut to use the computer name (without the domain) or to use localhost.

section.title: Configuration Requirements
section.para:
The Management Server has the following configuration requirements:
Create a new user or configure an existing user as an Administrator user for the Stealth Enterprise Manager services to run under.
Best Practice: It is a best practice to use a local user rather than a domain user.
This user must be included in the Local Administrator Group for the Management Server and assigned user rights to Log on as a service.
To configure (or verify) the user account you want to use for this purpose has the appropriate user rights, do the following:
Log on to the system you want to use as the Management Server using any administrator credentials.
Ensure that you have created a user that you want Stealth Enterprise Manager services to run under. If you have not yet done so, use the standard Windows method to add a user.
Do not use the user name “Administrator” or “portaladministrator” for this user; those names are reserved for use by internal Enterprise Manager functions.
If your Management Server is part of a domain, ensure that the user you want the Stealth Enterprise Management services to run under is configured as a user in that domain.
Access Windows Local Security Policy.
To do so, from the Start menu, enter Local Security Policy in the Search box.
In the Local Security Policy window, expand Local Policies.
Select User Rights Assignment.
Right-click Log on as a service, and then select Properties.
In the Log on as a service Properties dialog box, select Add User or Group to add the user that you want the Stealth Enterprise Manager services to run under.
In the dialog box that appears, ensure that the From this location box displays either the domain that the user belongs to or the local computer name, depending on whether you want the Enterprise Manager services to run under a domain user name or a local user name. (It is a best practice to use a local user rather than a domain user.)
If needed, click Locations and update the location.
In the Enter the object names to select box, enter the user name, and then click Check Names.
Click OK to close the open dialog boxes.
Ensure that the local or domain user you added is also included in the Local Administrator Group for the Management Server.
(Do not close the Local Security Policy window.)
Ensure that endpoint users you plan to authorize from the Management Server can Access this computer from the network.
Do the following:
On the Local Security Policy window, select User Rights Assignment.
Click Access this computer from the network, and ensure that the endpoint users you plan to authorize from the Management Server have access. For example, ensure that this field reads Everyone.
Close the Local Policy Security window.
Ensure that only one network adapter is enabled.
The Stealth software cannot be installed successfully if more than one network adapter is enabled. Do the following to disable additional network adapters:
From Control Panel, select Network and Internet.
Select Network and Sharing Center.
In the left pane, click Change adapter settings.
Disable all network adapters—except the one you want to use for Stealth communications—by right-clicking the network adapter and selecting Disable.
You can reenable additional network adapters after you complete the installation.
Close the Network and Sharing Center window.
Enable HTTP Activation and Microsoft Message Queueing Server (MSMQ).
Do the following to enable HTTP Activation and MSMQ (or verify that it is enabled):
