For Windows Server 2012 R2, do the following:
Access the Server Manager Dashboard, select the Manage tab, and then select Add Roles and Features.
If you see the Before you begin screen, click Next.
If you see the Select installation type screen, select Role-based or feature-based installation, and then click Next.
In the left menu, select Features.
In the center pane, expand .NET Framework 4.x Features.
Expand WCF Services, and then select HTTP Activation (if it is not already installed).
If this software is already installed, skip to the next step.
If this software is not already installed, in the Add Roles and Features dialog box, click Add Features.
In the Add Roles and Features wizard, in the center pane, expand Message Queuing, expand Message Queueing Services, and then select Message Queuing Server (if it is not already installed).
If this software is already installed, skip to the next step. If this software is not already installed, click Next, and then follow the prompts to install the software.
If you are prompted to close the wizard after installing the software, perform the first three steps to reopen the Add Roles and Features Wizard, Server Roles page.
In the left pane, select Server Roles (if it is not already selected).
In the center pane, under Web Server (IIS), under Web Server, select Common HTTP Features (if it is not already selected).
Click Next.
If you selected any software to install, select Confirmation in the left pane, and then proceed to the next step.
If you did not select any software to install, close the window and proceed to the next procedure.
On the Confirmation screen, click Install to install any additional software.
When the installation is complete, click Close.
If you previously installed the Stealth software, you must access Server Manager and restart the Unisys Stealth Authorization Service to complete the HTTP activation.
Set the Microsoft Message Queueing Server (MSMQ) service to restart if it encounters a failure.
Do the following:
Access Services. To do so, from the Start menu, enter services.msc in the Search box.
Locate the Message Queuing service in the list of services, right-click, and then select Properties.
On the Properties dialog box, click the Recovery tab.
In the First failure, Second failure, and Subsequent failures lists, select Restart the Service.
Click OK to close the Properties dialog box.
Close the Services window.
Manually set the correct date and time on the Management Server, or connect the Management Server to a Network Time Protocol (NTP) server.
If you change the date or time on the Management Server after the Enterprise Manager software is installed, you must reboot the Management Server.

section.title: Certificate Requirements
section.para: Enterprise Manager uses a signing certificate to protect the integrity of the settings.xml and crypto.xml files, which are included in the endpoint software package. The endpoint uses the trust chain (that is, the corresponding root and intermediate certificates) to validate the signing certificate, which is then used to validate these XML files before enabling Stealth.

For Stealth(aware), you must use the signing certificate and root certificate that are automatically generated when Enterprise Manager is initialized. When directed, you must import the trusted root certificate for the signing certificate onto each endpoint that you want to Stealth-enable.

section.title: Security Requirements
section.para:
The Management Server has the following security requirements:
Enable Active Scripting
Do the following:
Close all open browser windows.
From the Start menu, enter gpedit.msc in the Search box.
In the Local Group Policy Editor window, in the left pane under Computer Configuration, expand Administrative Templates, expand Windows Components, expand Internet Explorer, expand Internet Control Panel, expand Security Page, and then click Internet Zone.
Double-click Allow active scripting.
On the Allow active scripting dialog box, select the Enabled option, and then ensure that Enable appears in the Allow active scripting list (under Options).
Click OK to close the Allow active scripting dialog box.
In the left pane of the Local Group Policy Editor window, select Intranet Zone (under Security Page).
Double-click Allow active scripting.
On the Allow active scripting dialog box, select the Enabled option, and then ensure that Enable appears in the Allow active scripting list (under Options).
Click OK to close the Allow active scripting dialog box.
(Do not close the Local Group Policy Editor window.)
Enable Transport Layer Security (TLS) 1.2
Do the following:
In the Local Group Policy Editor window, in the left pane, click Advanced Page (which appears under Internet Control Panel that you expanded in the previous procedure).
In the right pane, double-click Turn off encryption support.
In the Turn off encryption support dialog box, select Enabled.
In the Options table, select the value under Secure Protocol combinations, and change the value to Only use TLS 1.2.
Click OK.
Reboot the Management Server.
After rebooting, log on using the user name that you want the Enterprise Manager services to run under, and then do the following to verify that the settings have been applied:
Open Internet Explorer.
On the Tools menu, select Internet options.
On the Internet Options dialog box, select the Advanced tab.
Under Security, verify that the Use TLS 1.2 check box is selected. Verify that all other Use SSL and Use TLS check boxes are cleared.
Click OK to close the Internet Options dialog box.

section.title: Resolution and Browser Requirements
section.para:
Enterprise Manager was tested using a resolution in the following range, and you should configure the Management Server with a screen resolution in this range:
Minimum resolution: 1152×864
Maximum resolution: 1440×900
If you are running Stealth(aware) on the Management Server, the recommended resolution is different than the recommended resolution for Enterprise Manager. You should use the recommended Stealth(aware) resolution. If this causes problems when using Enterprise Manager, you might need to temporarily change your resolution.

Ensure that one of the following browsers is installed on the Management Server:
Internet Explorer 11.x
Firefox 35 or later
Stealth Enterprise Manager was qualified using Internet Explorer 11.x and Firefox 35. Because Mozilla regularly releases new versions of Firefox, if you experience any problems with a later version of Firefox, it is recommended that you use Internet Explorer 11.x.

In addition, you must configure the following browser settings:
Ensure that the pop-up blocker is disabled.
Set the browser zoom level to 100%.
Enable cookies, as follows:
If you are using Internet Explorer, it is recommended (but not required) that you configure the Internet Options Privacy setting to Accept All Cookies, which provides the optimal performance when accessing Enterprise Manager.
If you are using Firefox, it is required that you set the browser to accept cookies. To do so, configure the Options Privacy setting to Accept cookies from sites, and set Accept third-party cookies to Always. Alternatively, click Exceptions and set an exception for the Enterprise Manager URL (by default, https://<computer name>:29080/).
If you are using Firefox, also do the following:
Set the browser cache to 15 MB or higher.
Do the following:
Open Firefox, and enter about:config into the address bar.
If you see a warning, click I’ll be careful, I promise.
In the Search box, enter browser.cache.disk.capacity.
Ensure that the value is at least 15360.
If the value is less than 15360, double-click browser.cache.disk.capacity, and enter a new value that is at least 15360.
Ensure that JavaScript is enabled.
Do the following:
In the Firefox about:config Search box, enter javascript.enabled.
Verify that javascript.enabled is set to true.
If it is set to false, right-click it, and click Toggle.
Close the Firefox window.

section.title: Software Installed During the Installation Process
section.para:
The following software will be installed during the installation process.
Windows .NET Framework version 4.6.1
If .NET Framework is already installed, the Stealth Enterprise Manager setup process checks the current version. .NET Framework version 4.6.1 is only installed if that version is not already present.
Visual C++ 2015 and 2010 (x86 and x64) Redistributables
Java™ SE Runtime Environment Version 8.0 (x64)
MySQL (MySQLVersion 5.6.27 and MySQL Connector/ODBC 5.3.4)
Liferay Portal 6.2, Tomcat Server 7.0.62 (for Enterprise Manager), Tomcat Server 8.0.36 (for Stealth EcoAPI), and Liferay (as a Windows service) 8.0.5
The Management Server must not be running any other version of Tomcat besides the version installed with the Enterprise Manager software. If the system on which you plan to install the Management Server is already running Tomcat, you must remove it before beginning the Enterprise Manager software installation.
Liferay Portal and Tomcat Server are installed by the Unisys LiferayTomcatService.msi installer, which has a Stealth Solution 3.x build version.
Tomcat Server runs as a Windows service, which is named Stealth Enterprise Manager. During the installation procedure, you are prompted to create a user name and password for this service. The default user name is Tomcatuser, but it can be changed to another unique user name in the environment that meets Windows user account naming conventions. The installation procedure creates a non-administrator user account configured to Log on as a service.
Pegasus (cimserver.exe) 2.12.0.0
Pegasus is installed as part of the Unisys Stealth Enterprise Manager installer.

section.title: Disabling NetBIOS on the Enabled Network Adapter
section.para:
When NetBIOS is enabled on the Management Server, it is a potential security risk. It is recommended that you disable NetBIOS on the remaining enabled network adapter. Do the following to disable NetBIOS.
You should have only one network adapter enabled, because you were instructed to disable all network adapters except the one you want to use for Stealth communications on the Management Server.
From the Start menu, enter Network and Sharing Center in the Search box.
In the left pane, click Change adapter settings.
Right-click the enabled network adapter, and select Properties.
On the network adapter Properties dialog box, double-click Internet Protocol Version 4 (TCP/IPv4).
On the Internet Protocol Version 4 (TCP/IPv4) Properties dialog box, click Advanced.
On the Advanced TCP/IP Settings dialog box, select the WINS tab.
On the WINS tab, select Disable NetBIOS over TCP/IP.
Click OK to close the Advanced TCP/IP Settings dialog box, click OK to close the Internet Protocol Version 4 (TCP/IPv4) Properties dialog box, and then click OK to close the network adapter Properties dialog box.
Close the Network Connections window.

section.title: Installing the Management Server Software
section.para: You install the Management Server software using the Unisys Stealth Solution Release 3.x ISO file. The ISO file includes two separate software installation packages: one for installing the Management Server software and one for installing the standalone Authorization Server software.

note.para: Standalone Authorization Servers are not supported for Stealth(aware). Do not install a standalone Authorization Server in your environment.

section.para: The installer checks that the prerequisite Management Server software (and correct software versions) are installed. If any prerequisite software is not yet installed, or if the wrong software level is installed, the installer launches various windows to guide you through that software installation. Once all of the prerequisite software packages are installed, the Enterprise Manager software is installed and launched.

note.para: Two logs are created in the C:\Stealth directory during the installation process: EMLiferayTomcatInstall.log and EMPortalInstall.log. If you experience any issues with the installation, you can refer to these logs.

section.para:
Complete the following steps to install the software on your Management Server:
Ensure that you met the Management Server requirements in .
Do not proceed with the installation until you meet the Management Server requirements. If you do not meet these requirements, the installation will fail.
Log on to the Management Server using the user name and password that the Stealth Enterprise Manager services should run under.
It is a best practice to use a local user rather than a domain user. You must be sure that the user is included in the Local Administrator Group for the Management Server and is assigned user rights to Log on as a service.
Ensure that the ISO file you downloaded is mounted to a local drive or extracted to a local drive.
You cannot install the Management Server software from a remote or shared drive.
If it does not run automatically, double-click the Autorun.exe file from the ISO file to launch the installer.
Be sure to select the Autorun Application (.exe), rather than the Autorun Setup Information file.
Click Yes if you are prompted to allow the installer to make changes to the computer.
The Unisys Stealth Solution Software CD screen appears.
Click the Install button next to Stealth Management Server software.
The open-source license for the Enterprise Manager Liferay Portal and Tomcat Server components appear.
Read the license terms that apply to Liferay Portal, Tomcat Server, as well as to MySQL Server, and then click Accept Terms.
The installer checks for prerequisite software that is not already installed and displays the first software installer. (Subsequent installers start automatically.)
If .NET Framework 4.6.1 is not already installed, click Upgrade to upgrade to the required version of .NET Framework.
If .NET Framework 4.6.1 is already installed (and you see a prompt to install Microsoft Visual C++ 2015 x86 Redistributable), skip to the next step.
Do the following to install .NET Framework if the installation screens for this software appear:
Wait while the software is extracted.
On the .NET Framework 4.6.1 Setup screen, read the license terms, select the I have read and accept the license terms check box, and then click Install.
Wait while the software is installed, which can take several minutes.
When the Installation Is Complete screen appears, click Finish.
If you are prompted to reboot your system, do so. Then, log back on using the user name and password that you want the Stealth Enterprise Manager services to run under, and relaunch the installation process by following the steps at the beginning of this procedure.
Wait while the Microsoft Visual C++ installation is launched.
Wait while the following software packages are automatically installed (if they are not already installed):
Microsoft Visual C++ 2015 x86 Redistributable
Microsoft Visual C++ 2015 x64 Redistributable
Microsoft Visual C++ 2010 x86 Redistributable
Microsoft Visual C++ 2010 x64 Redistributable
The Installer launches the Java Setup wizard, if Java version 8 is not already installed.
If Java version 8 is not already installed, do the following.
If Java version 8 is already installed, skip to the next step.
On the Java Setup – Welcome page, click Install.
Do not change the destination folder.
When you see the “You have successfully installed Java” screen, click Close.
When prompted, enter a password for the MySQL root account, confirm the password, and then click Next.
Make a note of this password and record it in a safe location; it is required if you update the Management Server software.
If this is a new MySQL installation, you can use the same password that you used to log on to the Management Server, or you can enter a unique password for MySQL.
The MySQL Installer launches. Wait while the software is installed.
When prompted, enter the password and confirm the password for the user name that you used to log on to the Management Server, and then click Next.
As described in , this user name must be included in the Administrator Group for the Management Server and must be assigned user rights to Log on as a service. This is the user name that the Enterprise Manager services will run under.
Wait until the Stealth Enterprise Manager prompt appears and asks: “Do you want to restore a previously saved Stealth configuration to the database for Stealth Enterprise Management?”
Click No (nothing to restore) for a new installation.
Wait for the Enterprise Manager software to be installed.
When you are prompted to configure the user account to be created for Tomcat Server, do the following:
Accept the default user name Tomcatuser, or enter a new user name in the Account name box.
If you enter a new user name, it must be unique in your environment.
Enter and confirm a password for Tomcat Server.
The password must be at least eight characters long, and it must include at least three of the following: uppercase letters, lowercase letters, numbers, and symbols. In addition, the user name cannot be included as part of the password.
You can use a password that you used previously, or you can enter a unique password.
Accept the default Tomcat Server port number of 29080, or enter a new port number.
This is the port that will be used to access Enterprise Manager.
Click Next
Wait while the Liferay Portal and Tomcat Server software is installed. It can take more than five minutes to install the Liferay Portal and Tomcat Server software.
The Tomcat Server user is configured with a password that never expires. Do not change this setting. If this password expires, you will be unable to log into Enterprise Manager.
When you are prompted to configure the user account to be created for the Stealth Ecosystem API (EcoAPI), do the following:
Accept the default user name ecoapiUser, or enter a new user name in the Account name box.
If you enter a new user name, it must be unique in your environment.
Enter and confirm a password for the EcoAPI.
The password must be at least eight characters long, and it must include at least three of the following: uppercase letters, lowercase letters, numbers, and symbols. In addition, the user name cannot be included as part of the password.
You can use a password that you used previously, or you can enter a unique password.
Accept the default EcoAPI port number of 8448, or enter a new port number.
This is the port that will be used to access the EcoAPI.
Click Next
Wait while the associated software is installed.
After the EcoAPI is installed, wait while the base Enterprise Manager software is installed and Stealth Enterprise Management Portal software is installed. This software installation can take several additional minutes to complete.
During the installation process, two icons are created on the Management Server desktop that enable you to
Uninstall the Unisys Stealth Enterprise Manager software (the icon is named “Uninstall Unisys Stealth Enterprise Management”)
Launch Enterprise Manager (the icon is named “Unisys Stealth Enterprise Management Portal”)
In addition, a shortcut is added to the Start menu that enables you to easily collect diagnostic information for the Management Server. To access the shortcut, from the Start menu, enter Collect Diagnostics in the Search box, right-click, and select Run as administrator. See the Unisys Stealth Solution Information Center for more information on collecting diagnostics.
When the installation is complete, on the Unisys Stealth Solution Software CD screen, you see “Status: Stealth Enterprise Management Portal [<version>] installed. Portal deployment successful.”
If the initial Enterprise Manager deployment fails, the installer automatically retries the deployment. Wait for Enterprise Manager to deploy successfully; the retry process can take several minutes to complete.
If you want to use your default browser, click Launch, and then wait while Enterprise Manager is configured and launched.
If you want to use another browser, click Close to close the installer, and then enter the following URL in a browser window:
https://<computer name>:<port number (by default, 29080)>/
The Management Server computer name must be able to be resolved by a Domain Name System (DNS) server or other name resolution mechanism. If the Management Server is in a domain, the shortcut created to launch Enterprise Manager uses the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) of the Management Server, and therefore the FQDN must be resolvable. If the computer name is not resolvable, you might have to manually update the shortcut to use the computer name (without the domain) or localhost.
After launching Enterprise Manager, enter the portal administrator user name and password, and then click Sign In.
For a new installation, the default user name is portaladmin and the default password is AdminPortal1#.
After you sign in, you see a screen that looks like the following: Enterprise Manager

section.title: Configuring the Authorization Service
section.para: Perform the following procedures to configure the Authorization Service.

section.title: Configuring the AuthService.config File
section.para: The AuthService.config file is used to configure the Authorization Service running on the Management Server. For Stealth(aware), you must configure two AuthGroups as described in this topic. One AuthGroup is used to authorize the Management Server, and the second AuthGroup is used to authorize all other endpoints in the environment.

Do the following to configure the AuthService.config file for Stealth(aware):
From the Start menu, enter Notepad in the Search box.
Right-click Notepad, and select Run as administrator.
If you are asked if you want to allow Notepad to make changes to this computer, click Yes.
In Notepad, select the File menu, and then click Open.
On the Open dialog box, change the file type from Text Documents (*.txt) to All Files.
Browse to the C:\Program Files\Unisys\Stealth Solution\USS-AuthServer directory and open Sample(aware)AuthService.config.
The Sample(aware)AuthService.config file includes two AuthGroups that are configured specifically for Stealth(aware).
Be sure to open the Sample(aware)AuthService.config file rather than the SampleAuthService.config file.
The SampleAuthService.config file applies to Stealth(core) and includes additional AuthGroups and Authorization Schemes that are not supported in Stealth(aware).
Open a new Notepad file using the Run as administrator option.
Copy the first line in the sample file (<AuthService version="3.x"> into the new Notepad file.
From the end of the sample file, copy the <AuthGroup> lines and the </AuthService> line into the new Notepad file.
The new file should look like the following: <AuthService version="3.2"> <AuthGroup name="Aware-Administration"> <Url>http://192.168.36.20:10200/</Url> <AdminUrl>http://127.0.0.1:10210/</AdminUrl> <AuthenticationScheme>IntegratedWindowsAuthentication </AuthenticationScheme> <CertAge>1825</CertAge> </AuthGroup>
<AuthGroup name="Aware-Project"> <Url>http://192.168.36.20:10300/</Url> <AdminUrl>http://127.0.0.1:10310/</AdminUrl> <AuthenticationScheme>IntegratedWindowsAuthentication </AuthenticationScheme> <CertAge>1825</CertAge> </AuthGroup>
</AuthService>
For each AuthGroup, do the following in the <Url> line:
If the Management Server uses SSL, update the http:// value to https://.
Change the example IP address (192.168.36.20) to the static IPv4 address of your Management Server.
Do not change the port numbers. Do not change the <AuthGroup name>, <AdminURL>, or <AuthenticationScheme>.
Optionally, for each AuthGroup, in the <CertAge> line, leave the default value or enter a new age (in days) for the certificate for the AuthGroup. (The certificate for the AuthGroup is created when you restart the Authorization Service as directed at the end of this procedure.)
The default value of 1825 days (or five years) is a standard for some self-signed certificates. Enter a value that is appropriate for your environment and security policies.
From the File menu, select Save As in the new Notepad file.
In the Save As dialog box, set the Save as type to All Files, enter the file name AuthService.config, and then click Save.
If you are prompted for encoding, accept the default.
Close the AuthService.config file, and close Notepad.
Using Windows Explorer, browse to C:\Program Files\Unisys\Stealth Solution\USS-AuthServer, and verify that the AuthService.config file is located in this directory and that it does not have an extension of .txt.
Open the file using Notepad, verify that your changes were saved, and then close Notepad.
From the Start menu, enter services.msc in the Search box to access the Services console.
Restart the Unisys Stealth Authorization Service so that the Authorization Service uses the AuthService.config file you saved.

section.title: Optionally Configuring SSL to Work with the Authorization Service
section.para:
If the Management Server is running SSL, and if you want to use SSL with the Authorization Service, do the following:
Obtain an Authorization Service SSL certificate for your server.
This certificate common name must match the fully qualified domain name, IP address, or host name that you entered for the Url in , which endpoints use to connect to the Authorization Service.
You can do any of the following:
Purchase certificate-management software and use the provided documentation to create and install the certificate.
Create and install your own self-signed certificate using a program such as MakeCert.
Contact a certificate authority, purchase a certificate, and then install it.
Install the Authorization Service SSL certificate in the Local Computer Personal key store.
Ensure that the trust chain for the certificate (including the trusted root certificate and any intermediate certificates) is installed in the Local Computer Trusted Root Certification Authorities key store.
Do the following to locate the certificate thumbprint for the SSL certificate on the MMC snap-in window:
Access the MMC utility, and run the Certificates snap-in.
To run the Certificates snap-in, select Add/Remove Snap-in from the File menu. Click Add, select Certificates and then click Add.
On the Certificates snap-in dialog box, verify that Computer account is selected, and then click Next.
Select Local computer, and then click Finish. Click Close on the Add Standalone Snap-in dialog box. Click OK on the Add/Remove Snap-in dialog box.
In the Certificates MMC snap-in window, in the left pane, expand Certificates (Local Computer), expand Personal, and then click Certificates.
In the right pane, double-click the SSL certificate.
Verify that the trust chain is valid. To do so, double-click the certificate, and then click the Certification Path tab. You should not see any errors stating that the trust chain could not be verified, and the Certificate status should read OK.
On the Certificate dialog box, click the Details tab, and scroll down to view the thumbprint.
Select the thumbprint value and copy it to the clipboard (press Ctrl+C).
Enter the following at a command prompt that is run as administrator.
In the following command, the <AuthGroup URL> and <port number> should be the same values you entered for the first AuthGroup in the AuthService.config file. However, note that in the AuthService.config file, you can enter either the server IP address or fully qualified domain name; for this command, you must enter the IP address.
Right-click and select Paste to paste all of the alphanumeric characters for the <certificate thumbprint>, and then delete the spaces.
In the following command, the appid value is not a variable; enter it exactly as specified.
Enternetsh http add sslcert ipport=<AuthGroup URL>:<port number> certhash=<certificate thumbprint> appid={350ad21e-58b2-4f19-aa0a-5e49e1d64de2}
For example, enternetsh http add sslcert ipport=192.168.233.34:9000 certhash=beda74645d906bd7e639e8c1ge99d774264cg1g9 appid={350ad21e-58b2-4f19-aa0a-5e49e1d64de2}
Verify your SSL certificate by entering the following command: netsh http show sslcert
For each additional AuthGroup that uses SSL, repeat the previous steps using the appropriate AuthGroup <Url> and <port number> in the netsh command.

section.title: Configuring a New Password and Configuring Licensing in Enterprise Manager
section.para:
Do the following to configure a new password for the portaladmin account and to configure Stealth licensing in Enterprise Manager:
If you have not already done so, launch Enterprise Manager by double-clicking the Unisys Stealth Enterprise Management Portal shortcut on the Management Server desktop.
Sign in to Enterprise Manager with the Portal Administrator account credentials. (The default user name is portaladmin and the default password is AdminPortal1#.)
Change the default portaladmin user account password by doing the following.
You must record this new password. It cannot be recovered.
Click Change Password in the upper-right corner of the page.
On the Change Password dialog box, enter the default password (AdminPortal1#) in the Old Password box.
Enter the new password in the New Password and Confirm New Password boxes.
The password must be between six and 50 characters, and it must include all of the following:
At least one uppercase letter
At least one lowercase letter
At least one number
At least one of the following special characters:
! @ # $ % ^ & * ( ) _ + =
Click Save.
Click Sign Out to sign out of Enterprise Manager, and then sign back in using the new password.
Install the local license file by doing the following.
The Management Server can have only one license file installed. See the Unisys Stealth Solution Information Center for more information on licensing.
Ensure that you have the Welcome Letter that you received with your order; you are instructed to enter the SCN that is provided in the Welcome Letter. (If you do not have the Welcome Letter, you can install temporary licenses.)
You can install temporary licenses in order to test your configuration. This temporary licenses provide 25 Client licenses, 25 Server licenses, 25 Mobile licenses (for remote users using SRA clients), and 25 VGD licenses (Virtual Gateway Device licenses for Clear Text endpoints that use the Secure Virtual Gateway) for 90 days. (However, note that Mobile licenses and VDG licenses cannot be used in conjunction with an environment configured using Stealth(aware).If you want to use these temporary licenses, perform the steps for temporary licenses in the following procedure.
Select Manage from the menu bar.
Select the License tab.
Click Install SCN at the bottom of the page.
On the Install SCN dialog box, enter the SCN that was provided in your Welcome Letter in the SCN box.
If you want to use temporary licenses, you can enter the SCN from the Welcome Letter, or you can enter any numeric string in the SCN box (for example, 1234567890). You can enter any number, but it must be unique within the configuration, and it cannot match another temporary SCN.
Ensure that the Management Server is selected in the System list.
Click Save.
Enterprise Manager installs the SCN. This process can take several minutes to complete.
Click the Refresh icon at the bottom of the License table to refresh the table and display the SCN that you installed.
After you install the SCN, a file with an encrypted license certificate is generated on the Management Server as a .blo file. The .blo file is located in the C:\Stealth Files\Certificates\ directory and is named according to your SCN.
To install temporary licenses do the following.
To install permanent licenses, skip to the next step.
Select the SCN row in the table.
Click Update License.
Enter Test in the License Key box and enter Licenses in the Verification Key box.
Click Save.
Skip to the final step in this procedure.
To install permanent licenses, do the following:
Log on to the Unisys Download Center as described in your Welcome Letter.
The Download Center Home page appears and displays your corporate contact information.
Select Download Management in the left pane.
In the Order Number box, enter the order number provided in your Welcome Letter, and click Submit.
On the Download Management page, under the Product Management heading, click the Stealth Software Licensing link that corresponds to your order number.
On the Stealth Software Licensing page, select the SCN that you installed on the Management Server from the SCN Number list and click Submit.
Click Browse next to the Encryption Certificate box, and browse to the .blo file that was generated by Enterprise Manager. This file was created in the C:\Stealth Files\Certificates\ directory and is named according to your SCN.
Click Update.
The Download Center provides a license file, which is an encrypted text file that contains your license keys.
Save and open the license file.
On the Enterprise Manager License tab, select the SCN for the license you are installing and click Update License.
On the Update License dialog box, copy the strings from the license file in the License Key box and Verification Key box.
If you open the text file in Notepad, it is recommended that you enable Word Wrap (by clicking Format and selecting Word Wrap) to ensure that you copy the full text of each string.
Click Save.
Enterprise Manager installs the licenses. This process can take several minutes.
Click the Refresh icon at the bottom of the License table to refresh the display with the updated license information. The Total License column displays the updated license count and the Status displays Installed Locally.
The licenses are installed and ready for use.

section.title: Configuring Enterprise Manager User Accounts
section.para: Best practice: It is a best practice to create at least one additional Enterprise Manager user account that is a Local User, and to assign it to the Portal Administrator role. You can use this account to complete the remaining configuration steps if you choose. At this time, you can also create as many additional accounts as are needed for Enterprise Manager users in your environment and assign them to the appropriate Enterprise Manager roles.

For example, you can assign one or more Enterprise Manager users to the Portal Administrator role to grant administrator privileges to those users and enable them to see all Enterprise Manager pages. In contrast, assigning users to the Audit Administrator role grants access only to the Monitor and Logs pages. You can add as many Enterprise Manager users as you want to your environment, assigned to whichever roles are appropriate for each user.

Enterprise Manager users (who are responsible for administering and operating the Stealth environment) and Stealth endpoint users (who are usually authenticated using Active Directory/LDAP and are assigned to roles) exist in the same Stealth database, and so each user name must be unique. If a person in your environment acts as both an Enterprise Manager user and a Stealth endpoint user, he or she requires two distinct user accounts: an Enterprise Manager user account and an endpoint user account.

formalpara.title: Adding Enterprise Manager Users
formalpara.para:
To add a new Enterprise Manager user, do the following:
Select Administration in the menu bar.
Select the User tab.
Click Add at the bottom of the page.
In the Add User dialog box, enter a unique display name for the new user in the Name box.
Enter a unique user ID in the User ID box.
For a list of supported characters in user IDs, see .
It is recommended that you add a prefix to each Enterprise Manager user name (in the User ID box) to ensure that there are no conflicts between Enterprise Manager users and endpoint users. For example, you could preface each Enterprise Manager user name with EM, such as EMOperator, EMAuditor, EMCrypto, and so on.
Optionally, enter a description for the user in the Description box.
Enter a password for the user in the Default Password box, and then reenter the password in the Confirm Password box.
The password must be between six and 50 characters, and it must include all of the following.
At least one uppercase letter
At least one lowercase letter
At least one number
At least one of the following special characters:
! @ # $ % ^ & * ( ) _ + =
Select the Local User check box.
Click Save.
When you are finished adding users, click Close.

formalpara.title: Assigning Enterprise Manager Users to Roles
formalpara.para:
The Administration page, Role tab includes a list of roles to which you can assign to Enterprise Manager users. Assigning an Enterprise Manager user to a role determines which Enterprise Manager pages the user can access and tasks the user can perform. Available roles include the following:
Audit Administrator
Purpose – Manages logs and monitors the systems added to Enterprise Manager
Access – Monitoring page and Logs page only
Cryptographic Administrator
Purpose – Manages Stealth roles, COIs, and filters
Access – All pages, except the Administration page; however, users in this role are restricted from the following:
Users have read-only access to the Monitoring page and all subtabs
Users cannot view the License subtab on the Manage page, and cannot install or delete license files
Portal Administrator
Purpose – Performs all administration functions in Enterprise Manager
Access – All pages and functions
Portal Operator
Purpose – Monitors systems
Access – Monitoring page only
Service Administration
Purpose – Provides for automatic updates performed by services in the environment
Access – All pages and functions
Stealth Administrator
Purpose – Manages the settings for systems in the Stealth network
Access – Full access to the Monitoring and Logs pages and the System subtab on the Configure page
Read-only access to the Provision page and all other subtabs (except System) on the Configure page

section.para: Click the plus sign (+) to the left of a role to display the users that have been assigned to the role.

To assign one or more Enterprise Manager users to a role, do the following.
You cannot modify an Enterprise Manager user’s roles or delete the user while you are logged on as that user. You must sign in with another Enterprise Manager user account with the necessary privileges (for example, portaladmin).
You cannot modify the portaladmin user’s roles or delete the user.
If you have not already done so, on the Administration page, select the Role tab.
Select the check box next to the role or roles that you want to assign to a user.
Click Show Users at the bottom of the page.
In the Add/Remove User dialog box, select the check box next to each user that you want to assign to the selected roles.
Click Save.

section.title: Using the StealthConfiguration Utility to Create Required Configurations

caution.para: In this procedure, you must spell and capitalize all commands exactly as written.

Therefore, you might want to do the following:
Copy-and-paste these commands from this document into a text editor.
Update the variables for your environment.
Remove the line breaks.
Paste the resulting command into the command prompt window by right-clicking and selecting Paste.

section.para:
The StealthConfiguration Utility is a command line utility that runs on the Management Server. Based on the values you enter, it does the following:
Creates an Administrative configuration that is used to configure the Management Server
Creates an endpoint configuration that is used to configure all other endpoints in the environment so that they can communicate with the Management Server and be authorized
Creates a Stealth endpoint package that must be installed on the Management Server
Creates Stealth endpoint packages that must be installed on all of the other systems in your environment that you want to Stealth-enable so that they can communicate with one another securely using Stealth

To use the StealthConfiguration Utility do the following:
Ensure that you are logged on to the Management Server as a local administrator user.
Open a command prompt using the Run as administrator option.
Enter the following command:cd "C:\Program Files\Unisys\EnterpriseMgmt\Stealth Manager"
If you need to create any clear text filters, do the following. For example, if the Management Server needs to communicate with an Active Directory server that will not be Stealth-enabled, you can create a clear text filter, or if the endpoints need to communicate with a Domain Name System (DNS) server that will not be Stealth-enabled, you can create a clear text filter.
You can use one clear text filter for the Management Server and use a different clear text filter for all other endpoints, or you can use one clear text filter that can be shared by the Management Server and by all endpoints.
Each clear text filter you create must have a unique name. You can create as many clear text filters as you choose, but you can only reference one clear text filter from the Management Server configuration and one clear text filter from the endpoint configuration.
Each clear text filter can include one or more of the following, in a comma-separated list:
IP address – Enter one or more IPv4 addresses
IP address range – Enter one or more IPv4 address ranges, separated by a hyphen or using CIDR notation. For example, enter 192.0.2.8-192.0.2.16 or enter 192.0.2.0/24.
IP address with specific ports or protocols – Enter one or more IPv4 addresses or address ranges with port or protocol filters, using the syntax <IP address>:<protocol from 0 to 254> or <IP address>:<UDP or TCP>[<wild card or local port>:<wild card or remote port>]. For example, enter 198.51.100.3:20 or 198.51.100.3:TCP[*:53].
To create one or more clear text filters, do the following:
Enter the following command:StealthConfiguration.exe -v ClearTextFilterName="<Filter Name>" ClearTextFilter="<IP address or addresses>"
Ensure that you spell and capitalize these commands exactly as written.
The -v option enables verbose mode and provides additional feedback on the results of the command. You should see feedback as the filter is created.
Wait a brief time while the command is processed and the filter is created. When the processing is complete, you receive the command prompt.
If you need to create additional clear text filters, reenter the command using a unique filter name and an updated IP address or list of IP addresses.
For example, if you want to configure one filter set to communicate with a DNS server that will be used by both the Management Server and the endpoints, you could enter the following command:StealthConfiguration.exe ClearTextFilterName="DNS" ClearTextFilter="192.0.2.8"
In another example, if you want to configure one filter set for an Active Directory server for the Management Server, and configure a second filter set for the endpoints to communicate with the Active Directory server and with DNS servers on an IP address range using TCP port 53, you could enter the following command:StealthConfiguration.exe ClearTextFilterName="MS_AD" ClearTextFilter="192.0.2.10"
StealthConfiguration.exe ClearTextFilterName="EP_DNS" ClearTextFilter= "192.0.2.10,198.51.100.1-198.51.100.5:TCP[*:53]"
To create the configurations for your Management Server and endpoints, enter the following command:StealthConfiguration.exe -v StealthConfigName="<Admin Configuration Name>" ClearTextFilterName="<Optional Management Server filter>" AdminType=AwareAdmin AdminUserName="<Admin User Name>" AdminAuthorizationPort=10200 UserAuthorizationPort=10300 IPAddress="<Management Server IP Address>" ProjectName="<Endpoint Configuration Name>" ProjectClearTextFilterName= "<Optional endpoint filter>"
Ensure that you spell and capitalize these commands exactly as written.
The -v option enables verbose mode and provides additional feedback on the results of the command. You should see feedback as the configurations are created.
The following is a description of each of these values:
Value
Required/ Optional
Explanation
StealthConfigName=“<Admin Configuration Name>”
Required
Enter a name for the Administrative configuration used by the Management Server. For example, enter StealthConfigName=“AwareAdmin”.
ClearTextFilterName=“<Optional Management Server filter>”
Optional
If you created a clear text filter you want to use in the Administrative configuration for the Management Server, enter the name of a filter you configured in the previous step. For example, enter ClearTextFilterName=“MS_AD”.
AdminType=AwareAdmin
Required
This is not a variable. Enter this value exactly as specified.
AdminUserName=“<Admin User Name>”
Required
Enter the name of the Administrator user that you configured the Stealth Enterprise Manager services to run under. For example, enter “AdminUserName=“EMAdmin”
AdminAuthorizationPort=10200 Required
This is not a variable. Enter this value exactly as specified.
UserAuthorizationPort=10300 Required
This is not a variable. Enter this value exactly as specified.
IPAddress=“<Management Server IP Address>”
Required
Enter the static IPv4 address of the Management Server. For example, enter IPAddress=“198.51.100.10”.
ProjectName=“<Endpoint Configuration Name>”
Required
Enter a name for the for the endpoint configuration. For example, enter ProjectName=”AwareEndpoints”.
ProjectClearTextFilterName= ”<Optional endpoint filter>”
Optional
If you created a clear text filter you want to use in the endpoint configuration, enter the name of a filter you configured in the previous step. For example, if you created a filter named EP_DNS, enter ProjectClearTextFilterName=”EP_DNS”.
For example, enter the following: StealthConfiguration.exe -v StealthConfigName="AwareAdmin" ClearTextFilterName="MS_AD" AdminType=AwareAdmin AdminUserName="EMAdmin" AdminAuthorizationPort=10200 UserAuthorizationPort=10300 IPAddress="198.51.100.10" ProjectName="AwareEndpoints" ProjectClearTextFilterName="EP_DNS"
Wait a brief time while the configurations and endpoint packages are created.
When the processing is complete, you receive the command prompt.
To verify that the configurations and endpoint packages were created, do the following:
Using Windows Explorer, navigate to C:\Stealth Files\SoftwareInstalls\Packages.
Verify that the following six endpoint packages were created:
<Admin Configuration Name>AwareWinPkg64-SAO.exe
<Endpoint Configuration Name>AwareLinuxPkg-SAO.sh
<Endpoint Configuration Name>AwareWinPkg32-SAO.exe
<Endpoint Configuration Name>AwareWinPkg32-COD.exe
<Endpoint Configuration Name>AwareWinPkg64-SAO.exe
<Endpoint Configuration Name>AwareWinPkg64-COD.exe
If you do not see all of these endpoint packages, or if you want to delete your configurations and begin again, see .

section.title: Installing the Stealth Endpoint Package on the Management Server
section.para: To finalize the initial configuration of your Management Server, you must install the Stealth endpoint package that was automatically created for you by the StealthConfiguration Utility and then configure Windows Server Mode.

caution.para: This action will prevent the Management Server from communicating with any other systems in the environment (besides those for which it includes a clear text filter), because no other systems should be running the Stealth endpoint software at this time.

section.para:
Do the following:
Browse to the C:\Stealth Files\Software Installs\Packages directory on the Management Server.
Double-click <Admin Configuration Name>AwareWinPkg64-SAO.exe.
If you are prompted to allow the program to make changes to the computer, click Yes.
The Stealth installer window appears, and you see several messages that the Stealth services are started. When the installation is complete, the installer window closes, and the Stealth Dashboard appears in the task bar.
Do the following to configure Windows Server Mode on the Management Server:
From the Start menu, enter services.msc in the Search box to access the Services.
Locate the Unisys Stealth Logon service in the list of installed services.
Be sure to locate the Unisys Stealth Logon service (rather than the Unisys Stealth PreLogon service or the Unisys Stealth Protocol service).
Right-click the Unisys Stealth Logon service and select Properties.
On the Properties dialog box, select the Log On tab, and then select the This account option.
The user account you set to run in Server Mode must be in the administrators group on the local computer. If this is a domain\user name, the domain user must be added to the local computer administrators group.
Enter the user name and password for the Stealth network. (These are the user credentials that determine the Stealth role and COIs when Stealth is enabled on the server.)
When the user name is set in the account properties and a domain user account is being associated with the service, the administrator must use NT4 format (DOMAIN\username for a domain user or .\username for a local user). The default UPN format (username@www.domain.com) cannot be used because of the problem described in the Microsoft Knowledge Base article 955641. For more information, go to http://support.microsoft.com/kb/955641.
By default, when using the Browse/Check Names functionality in the Services MMC Snap-in, domain accounts are returned in UPN format. This means that you must change the format of the account name to NT4 style explicitly. This also means that you must know the NetBIOS name of the domain (as the UPN format uses the fully qualified domain name). If you do not know the NetBIOS name of the domain, you should contact your network administrator.
Click OK to close the dialog box.
Click OK when you receive a warning that the changes do not take effect until you restart the service.
Close the Services window.
Reboot the server.
If you see a dialog box that requests Stealth credentials, you can click Cancel and continue with the reboot.
Stealth is enabled on the Management Server, and the Management Server can now communicate only with systems for which it has a clear text filter configured.

chapter.title: Deploying the Stealth(aware) Model
chapter.para: After you configure your Stealth(core) environment as described in , use the topics in this section to deploy Stealth policies to your environment based on the Stealth(aware) Model.

note.para: There is no requirement to add the Stealth Management Server Profile to the Enterprise Manager Solution or to any other Solution. You configured the Management Server manually as described in , and therefore you do not need to incorporate it into any Solution using Stealth(aware).

section.title: Deploying Solutions to Enterprise Manager

note.para: If you set the Affinity Level to Off, you cannot use this tool.

section.para: Using Stealth(aware), do the following to deploy your Solutions to Enterprise Manager.

listitem.para: Before you deploy your Solutions, ensure that you manually updated the Solution name. Updating the Solution name ensures that auto modeling will not make any changes to those Solutions after you deploy them.
For example, you could append _D (for deployed) for each Solution name you intend to deploy.

In general, you should deploy all Solutions in your project each time you deploy. You can choose to not deploy a particular Solution only if that Solution is not ready for deployment. In that case, you can continue configuring the Solution and deploy it at a later time. Note the following:
If a Solution includes Stealth-enabled Profiles, all of the required objects are created in Enterprise Manager (including configurations, COIs, roles, and filters).
If a Solution does not include Stealth-enabled Profiles, the required clear text filters to enable communication to those Nodes are created in Enterprise Manager.
If a Solution does not include at least one Profile, it is ignored.
If the Solution has been previously deployed (even if you made no changes to the Solution) you must select it to be deployed, or it will be deleted from Enterprise Manager.

section.para:
To deploy one or more Solutions using the Deploy tool, do the following:
On the map, click the Deploy tool.
The map turns gray and a panel appears that prompts you to select options and then click Deploy.
Under Select an enforcement level for deployment, optionally select a new enforcement level from the list. This setting provides a guideline for the filters that are created by Stealth(aware); however, filtering is also dependent on Channel policies and whether or not the connection is in clear text.
You initially configured this setting in . If you change this value on the Deploy panel, it will be updated in the Project Details panel as well, and future deployments will use this updated setting by default.
Optionally update the value and select one of the following:
Enforce IP Addresses and Services – Filters are generated to enforce IP addresses and both local and remote ports.
Enforce IP Addresses – Filters are generated to enforce local ports on the providing services and IP addresses on the consuming profiles.
Enforce Services – Filters are generated to enforce local ports on the services.
Don’t enforce either IP Addresses or Services – Filters are only generated when they are required.
Under Select the Solutions you want to deploy, select the check box for each Solution that you want to deploy, or click Clear/Select All to clear the list or select all check boxes.
You can choose to not deploy a particular Solution only if that Solution is not ready for deployment. In that case, you can continue configuring the Solution and deploy it at a later time.
However, if the Solution has been previously deployed (even if you made no changes to the Solution) you must select it to be deployed, or the associated objects created in Enterprise Manager will be deleted and the associated Nodes will not be able to use Stealth to communicate.
Select one of the following options:
Create Objects Only
If you select Create Objects Only, an XML file is created that enables Stealth objects to be created in Enterprise Manager, but the Solutions are not automatically deployed. You can view the created objects in Enterprise Manager, and then use Enterprise Manager to provision the Stealth environment.
Create and Deploy
If you select Create and Deploy, an XML file is created that enables Stealth objects to be created in Enterprise Manager, and the Solutions are then automatically deployed. (There is no opportunity to review the created objects in Enterprise Manager before the Stealth environment is provisioned.) It is a best practice to select this option, because it simplifies deployment and can help to avoid errors in using Enterprise Manager.
For either option you select, a window appears that prompts you to save the project as an XML file.
The default name for each file is Deployment<Year>-<Month>-<Day>_<Hours>-<Minutes>-<Seconds>_GMT in Greenwich Mean Time (GMT).
Browse to any location and save the project.
The Deploy tool closes.
If Stealth(aware) is not running on the Management Server, proceed to .
If Stealth(aware) is running on the Management Server, do the following:
From the PowerShell window that appears, enter the user name and password when prompted.
The credentials that you enter must be for a member of the Enterprise Manager Portal Administrator, Cryptographic Administrator, or Service Administration group.
Wait while the script executes. You can monitor the progress of the script execution from one of the following:
The PowerShell console
The log file, which is located in the directory where you saved the project using the project name. By default, this file is named Deployment<Year>-<Month>-<Day>_<Hours>-<Minutes>-<Seconds>_GMT.log.
After the PowerShell script is successfully executed, the following message appears:
Deploy Project <name of the project file> successfully completed.
If there are errors and the execution of the script is not successful, refer to the log file and retry the deployment if necessary with corrected input.
The configuration is visible in Enterprise Manager.
If you selected Create Objects Only from the Deploy tool, do the following.
If you selected Create and Deploy, the Stealth(aware) Model has been provisioned to the network, and you are ready to install the Stealth endpoint software on any system that you want to use Stealth for secure communications. See .
Sign in to Enterprise Manager.
View the created objects in Enterprise Manager.
You should use Enterprise Manager to view objects and provision only; you must not make any changes to the objects using Enterprise Manager. If you make any changes using Enterprise Manager, those changes will not be reflected in Stealth(aware); this means that your configuration and Stealth(aware) map will not be synchronized and a new deployment from Stealth(aware) could disable Stealth communications that you configured using Enterprise Manager.
Therefore, if you see any objects that you want to change while reviewing the configuration in Enterprise Manager, return to Stealth(aware) to make the changes, and then select the Deploy tool again.
Do either of the following to provision the environment:
Return to Stealth(aware), select the Deploy tool, and select the Create and Deploy option.
In Enterprise Manager, use the standard method to provision. See the Unisys Stealth Solution Information Center for more information.

section.title: Copying and Deploying the Project File to Enterprise Manager

note.para: If Stealth(aware) is running on the Management Server, skip this topic.

section.para:
If Stealth(aware) is running on a system other than the Management Server, you must transfer the project file you created to the Management Server. You must then run a PowerShell script to populate Enterprise Manager, and then—depending on whether you selected the Create Objects Only or the Create and Deploy option from the Deploy tool—either automatically or manually deploy the model onto your network. Do the following:
If you have not already done so, copy the project file that you deployed from Stealth(aware) to any location on the Management Server.
By default, this file is named Deployment<Year>-<Month>-<Day>_<Hours>-<Minutes>-<Seconds>_GMT.xml.
On the Management Server, open a PowerShell window and enter the following command: cd "C:\Program Files\Unisys\EnterpriseMgmt\ EcoAPI\discovery\bin"
Enter the following command to execute the deploy project script:.\Deploy-Project.ps1 -xml <directory\project file name>.xml
Where <directory\project file name> is the full path to the project file that you want to deploy. For example, C:\Windows\temp\Deployment2017-2-17_22-25-20_GMT.xml.
When prompted, reenter the user name and enter the password for the Enterprise Manager Portal Administrator, Cryptographic Administrator, or Service Administration user.
Wait while the script executes. You can monitor the progress of the script execution from one of the following:
The PowerShell console
The log file, which is located in the directory where you saved the project using the project name. By default, this file is named Deployment<Year>-<Month>-<Day>_<Hours>-<Minutes>-<Seconds>_GMT.log.
When the execution of the PowerShell script is successful, the following message appears:
Deploy Project <name of the project file> successfully completed.
If there are errors and the execution of the script is not successful, refer to the log file and retry the deployment if necessary with corrected input.
The configuration is visible in Enterprise Manager.
If you selected Create Objects Only from the Deploy tool, do the following.
If you selected Create and Deploy, the Stealth(aware) Model has been provisioned to the network, and you are ready to install the Stealth endpoint software on any system that you want to use Stealth for secure communications. See .
Sign in to Enterprise Manager.
View the created objects in Enterprise Manager.
You should use Enterprise Manager to view objects and provision only; you must not make any changes to the objects using Enterprise Manager. If you make any changes using Enterprise Manager, those changes will not be reflected in Stealth(aware); this means that your configuration and Stealth(aware) map will not be synchronized and a new deployment from Stealth(aware) could disable Stealth communications that you configured using Enterprise Manager.
Therefore, if you see any objects that you want to change while reviewing the configuration in Enterprise Manager, return to Stealth(aware) to make the changes, and then select the Deploy tool again.
Do either of the following to provision the environment:
Return to Stealth(aware), select the Deploy tool, and select the Create and Deploy option.
In Enterprise Manager, use the standard method to provision. See the Unisys Stealth Solution Information Center for more information.

section.title: Continuing After Deployment
section.para: After the Stealth(aware) Model has been provisioned to the network, you are ready to install the Stealth endpoint software on any system that you want to use Stealth for secure communications. See .

note.para: If you have already installed the Stealth endpoint software on all endpoints, all tasks are complete.

chapter.title: Installing Stealth Endpoint Software
chapter.para: When you run the StealthConfiguration Utility (as described in ), the required Stealth endpoint packages are created in the C:\Stealth Files\Software Installs\Packages directory on the Management Server. When you use the Deploy tool in Stealth(aware), you provision the Stealth Management Server so that it can authorize endpoints and assign them to the appropriate roles and COIs.

You use the following endpoint packages to install the Stealth software on the workstations and servers that you want to Stealth-enable:
<Endpoint Configuration Name>AwareWinPkg32-SAO.exe
Windows 32-bit, Server Always On – Use this package to configure Windows 32-bit operating systems.
This mode is generally used for servers or any unattended system in the environment that need to run Windows Server Mode. Stealth is enabled when the system boots and cannot be disabled using the Stealth Dashboard.
<Endpoint Configuration Name>AwareWinPkg32-COD.exe
Windows 32-bit, Client On Demand – Use this package to configure Windows 32-bit operating systems.
This mode is generally used for Windows workstations or any regularly attended Windows system in the environment. Stealth is disabled when the system boots. Stealth remains disabled until the user specifically enables it using the Stealth Dashboard.
<Endpoint Configuration Name>AwareWinPkg64-SAO.exe
Windows 64-bit, Server Always On – Use this package to configure Windows 64-bit operating systems.
This mode is generally used for servers or any unattended system in the environment that need to run Windows Server Mode. Stealth is enabled when the system boots and cannot be disabled using the Stealth Dashboard.
<Endpoint Configuration Name>AwareWinPkg64-COD.exe
Windows 64-bit, Client On Demand – Use this package to configure Windows 64-bit operating systems. This mode is generally used for Windows workstations or any regularly attended Windows system in the environment. Stealth is disabled when the system boots. Stealth remains disabled until the user specifically enables it using the Stealth Dashboard.
<Endpoint Configuration Name>AwareLinuxPkg-SAO.sh
Linux, Server Always On – Use this package to configure all Linux endpoints (32-bit or 64-bit). Stealth can be enabled or disabled using a command.

Copy these endpoint packages to the workstations and servers on which you want to install Stealth, and use the appropriate endpoint package based on the operating system type, architecture, and behavior.

note.para: Do not install the <Admin Configuration Name>AwareWinPkg64-SAO.exe package on any system except the Management Server.

chapter.para:
Best Practice: Before you begin the endpoint software installation, it is a best practice to do the following:
Ensure that the workstations and servers that you want to Stealth-enable have network connectivity and are on a network segment that would be able access the Management Server.
Ensure that there are no firewalls blocking Stealth communications. For details on configuring firewalls to enable Stealth communications, see the Unisys Stealth Solution Information Center.

section.title: Configuring Windows Endpoints to Use Stealth
section.para: Perform the following procedures to install and configure the Stealth endpoint software on supported Windows operating systems.

section.title: Windows Endpoint Requirements
section.para:
The following are supported Windows operating systems (all versions):
Windows 7
Windows Server 2008 R2
Windows Server 2008 R2 Clustering is also supported.
Windows 8 and Windows 8.1
Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 R2
Windows 10

In addition, all Windows endpoints meet the following requirements:
.NET Framework version 3.5 with Service Pack 1 or .NET Framework version 4.x
Verify that the version of .NET Framework that you want to use is installed and activated using Control Panel, Programs and Features, or using Server Manager Dashboard (depending on the Windows operating system).
For Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2 only: Verify that the following Windows security update and hotfix patches are installed.
“Availability of SHA-2 Code Signing Support for Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2 (KB3033929)” – Included in Windows Update and available at https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=46148
“The Untrusted publisher dialog box appears when you install a driver in Windows 7 or Windows Server 2008 R2 (KB2921916)” – Windows hotfix included on the Unisys Stealth Solution Release ISO file as Windows6.1KB2921916-<x64 or x86>.msu
“Kernel-Mode Driver Framework version 1.11 update for Windows Vista, Windows Server 2008, Windows 7, and Windows Server 2008 R2 (KB2685811)” – Included in Windows Update and available at https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=38423
If you install any of these security updates, you must reboot your endpoint before continuing with the Stealth software installation.
In addition, you must also meet the memory requirements for the specific Windows operating system.

section.title: Importing the Trust Chain for the Endpoint Package Signing Certificate on Windows Endpoints
section.para: A signing certificate is used to protect the integrity of the settings.xml and crypto.xml files, which are included in the endpoint software package. The XML files in the endpoint software package are signed, and that signature is verified by the signing certificate.

The trusted root certificate for the default signing certificate, which is created by Enterprise Manager, is located on the Management Server in the C:\Stealth Files\Certificates directory, and it is named Unisys Stealth Root. Before proceeding, copy the Unisys Stealth Root trusted root certificate from this directory and import it to the Local Computer/Trusted Root Certification Authorities store on each endpoint.

note.para: The signing certificate is automatically included in the endpoint package, which means that the signing certificate does not have to be imported on any endpoints.

caution.para: If you do not import the required certificates, the endpoint cannot be authorized and the Stealth service cannot be started.

section.title: Optionally Disabling Stealth on Selected Network Adapters
section.para: Perform one of the following procedures to disable Stealth on network adapters.

formalpara.title: Disabling Stealth on Selected Network Adapters (Before Endpoint Software Installation or Upgrade)
formalpara.para: By default, Stealth is enabled on all network adapters on the Windows endpoint when Stealth endpoint software is installed or upgraded (excepting known virtual adapters that Stealth does not bind to, such as VPN adapters). If the system has multiple network adapters, you can disable Stealth for selected adapters before the endpoint installation or upgrade using the Stealth Network Adapter Exclusion Utility.

section.para: When you run this utility, a new registry key is written to the Windows Endpoint Registry, and the changes are applied during the next Stealth endpoint software installation or upgrade to a later version of Stealth endpoint software. You can rerun this utility at any time to update the registry.

note.para: If you run this utility to make changes to the registry entry, and then install the same version of endpoint software again, your changes will not take effect. You must uninstall and reinstall the Stealth software or upgrade to a later version of endpoint software to apply the changes from the registry.

section.para: These changes persist when the endpoint is rebooted and if the endpoint software is upgraded or uninstalled.
Do the following:

listitem.para: On Unisys Stealth Solution Release 3.x ISO file, navigate to the support directory, and copy the Stealth Network Adapter Exclusion Utility file, which is named ExcludeAdapters.exe.
Save this file to your endpoint, and run it on the endpoint by double-clicking ExcludeAdapters.exe.
In the Network Adapters Available to Stealth list, select a network adapter that you want to exclude, and then click Exclude.

note.para: If any network adapters that you want to exclude do not appear in the list, close the utility, ensure that the network adapters are connected and enabled in Windows, and then reopen the utility.

listitem.para: Repeat the previous step to exclude as many network adapters as needed.
In the Stealth Adapter Exclusion List, ensure that all of the network adapters you want to exclude are listed.
If there are any network adapters that appear in this list that you want to be Stealth enabled, you can remove them.
Click Save.
A new registry entry is written to HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Unisys\MLSTPGW named ExcludeDeviceNames.

formalpara.title: Updating Selected Network Adapters (After Endpoint Software Installation)
formalpara.para:
Alternatively, after the endpoint software is installed, you can disable Stealth for selected adapters by doing the following:
Access Control Panel, and select Network and Sharing Center.
Access the Local Area Connection Properties for the network adapter for which you want to disable Stealth.
On the properties dialog box, clear the "Unisys Stealth Solution" check box, and then click OK.

section.title: Installing Stealth Endpoint Software on Windows
section.para:
Do the following to install the Stealth endpoint software on Windows endpoints on all systems running supported Windows operating systems in the environment that you want to Stealth-enable. After you meet the prerequisites, you can either perform the procedure in or .
For licensing purposes, you should install the endpoint software first on the Management Server before installing it on other Windows endpoints.

section.title: Prerequisites
section.para:
Before you begin installing the Stealth endpoint software on Windows endpoints, do the following:
Ensure that you met all of the Windows endpoint requirements in .
Ensure that the trusted root certificate (and any required intermediate certificates) have been imported to the Windows endpoint, as described in .
If you do not meet these prerequisites, the Stealth endpoint software cannot be installed. The installation process will terminate and you will receive an error code that describes the problem. Additional information on the error will be available in the Windows Application Event Log.

section.title: Manual Installation Procedure (Non-Silent)
section.para:
If you want to manually install the Stealth endpoint software on Windows endpoints, do the following:
Browse to the C:\Stealth Files\Software Installs\Packages directory on the Management Server.
If you entered a name in the Package File Name box when you created the endpoint package, the .exe appears in the Packages directory with that name. If you did not enter a name in the Package File Name box, the .exe file appears in the Packages\<software level> directory.
Copy the endpoint package to the endpoint (for example, using an external storage device or on a share that is accessible to the endpoint).
On the endpoint, double-click the endpoint package .exe file to install the Stealth software.
If you are prompted to allow the program to make changes to the computer, click Yes.

The Stealth installer window appears, and you see several messages that the Stealth services are started. When the installation is complete, the installer window closes, and the Stealth Dashboard appears in the task bar. The Stealth Dashboard appears red until Stealth is enabled.
For all servers, continue by configuring Windows Server mode, as described in .

section.title: Silent Installation Procedure
section.para: If you want to silently install the Stealth endpoint software on Windows endpoints, enter the following command using a command prompt window on the endpoint, or programmatically distribute and install this software using a software distribution system, such as System Center Configuration Manager (SCCM).

listitem.para: By default, when silent installation is run, the executable file terminates without waiting for the installation to complete. To wait for the installation to complete before terminating the endpoint package executable file, preface the command with Windows command start /wait.
Alternatively, to run the endpoint package executable file with silent options from a Windows script (such as PowerShell or VBScript), use the command shell Run and specify the wait option.

Depending on the system settings and how the installer is run, silently installing the Stealth endpoint software might result in the appearance of a Windows User Account Control (UAC) pop-up message. For information on UAC and options to manage it for silent installations, see the following Microsoft TechNet article:

para.emphasis: Silent Installation for a Server Using a User Name and Password for Server Mode

section.para: For a server on which you want to configure Server Mode using a user name and password, enter the following command from an Administrator command prompt to install Stealth silently. This command configures Server Mode by assigning the service user credentials to the Unisys Stealth Logon service.
For example, enter C:\temp\Winpackage.exe -ap "/qn /serviceuser=Admin.loc\AdminUser /servicepw=resU*nimdA"

listitem.para: The user must belong to the local Administrators group.

The user can be a local user or a domain user. If you do not enter a domain, the command assumes that the user is part of the local domain (.\user). If you do enter a domain, you can enter either the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) or the domain short name; for example, /serviceuser=[<domain>\]<user>.

If you use a domain user, either the Active Directory server must be Stealth-enabled and the endpoint package must be configured as Stealth Always On, or the endpoint package must include a clear text filter to the Active Directory server. (You cannot use a Stealth On Demand endpoint package if the Active Directory server is Stealth-enabled, because Stealth is not enabled on the endpoints at the time that the Stealth Logon Service starts, when authentication with the Stealth-enabled Active Directory server is required.)

section.para:
Additionally, you can add the following options to the command:
/nomsu – Add this option to skip the check for required Windows updates for Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2, if you know that all updates are installed on the endpoint.
/nodiag – Add this option to skip the diagnostic collection that occurs, in the event of a failed installation and roll back.
If there are any problems encountered during installation on the endpoints, they are listed in the log file C:\Stealth\StealthEP_Install.log and in the Windows Application Event log.

section.title: Configuring Server Mode Using a User Name
section.para: Any Windows server that runs Stealth software should be configured to run with Server Mode enabled so that the server is automatically Stealth-enabled whenever it reboots. In general, any unattended system should be configured to run with Server Mode enabled. This includes the Management Server as well as Stealth-enabled AD servers, DNS servers, DHCP servers, NTP servers, Syslog servers, database servers, and web servers. (Your Stealth network might not include all of these types of servers.) Perform this procedure after you install the Stealth endpoint software on the server to configure the account that is used by the Unisys Stealth Logon service.

note.para: If you configured silent installation, and if you entered the command to assign the service user credentials to the Unisys Stealth Logon service, skip this procedure. (Server mode is already configured.)

section.para: To configure Server Mode using a user name, perform the following procedure.

Do the following:
Log in with a user name that has the appropriate authority to modify services, typically an administrative user name.
Access Services. To do so, from the Start menu, enter services.msc in the Search box to access the Services.
Locate the Unisys Stealth Logon service in the list of installed services.
Be sure to locate the Unisys Stealth Logon service (rather than the Unisys Stealth PreLogon service or the Unisys Stealth Protocol service).
Right-click the Unisys Stealth Logon service and select Properties.
On the Properties dialog box, select the Log On tab, and then select the This account option.
The user account you set to run in Server Mode must be in the administrators group on the local computer. If this is a domain\user name, the domain user must be added to the local computer administrators group.
Enter the user name and password for the Stealth network. (These are the user credentials that determine the Stealth role and COIs when Stealth is enabled on the server.)
When the user name is set in the account properties and a domain user account is being associated with the service, the administrator must use NT4 format (DOMAIN\username). The default UPN format (username@www.domain.com) cannot be used because of the problem described in the Microsoft Knowledge Base article 955641. For more information, go to http://support.microsoft.com/kb/955641.
By default, when using the Browse/Check Names functionality in the Services MMC Snap-in, domain accounts are returned in UPN format. This means that you must change the format of the account name to NT4 style explicitly. This also means that you must know the NetBIOS name of the domain (as the UPN format uses the fully qualified domain name). If you do not know the NetBIOS name of the domain, you should contact your network administrator.
Click OK to close the dialog box.
Click OK when you receive a warning that the changes do not take effect until you restart the service.
Close the Services window.
Reboot the server.
If you see a dialog box that requests Stealth credentials, you can click Cancel and continue with the reboot.

section.title: Enabling Stealth on Windows Endpoints
section.para: The Stealth Dashboard provides a method for you to enable and disable the Stealth service, if this option is allowed in your environment. (You might not be permitted to disable Stealth.) The Stealth Dashboard also provides status information on your current Stealth configuration.

You can access the Stealth Dashboard by clicking the Stealth Shield icon in the task bar. If the Dashboard does not appear in the task bar, you can access it from the Start menu by typing Stealth Dashboard in the Search box.

The following options are provided on the Main page of the Stealth Dashboard, depending on whether Stealth is configured as Always On or On Demand, as follows:
