If Stealth is configured as Always On, the configurations are automatically contacted in the order in which they were configured, until a connection is established or until there are no more configurations available. (You cannot disable Stealth.)
If Stealth is configured as On Demand
If you have more than one configuration, ensure that the configuration you want to connect to is shown in the Connect to list. If you cannot connect to that configuration, you can select a different configuration that you want to connect to.
Click Connect to connect to the selected configuration.
If you have only one configuration, click Connect to connect to that configuration.
For more information, click Help.

section.title: Configuring Linux Endpoints to Use Stealth
section.para: Perform the following procedures to install and configure the Stealth endpoint software on supported Linux operating systems.

note.para: When you install the Stealth endpoint software on Linux operating systems, the only existing system file that is modified is /etc/group. A new group is added to /etc/group, which is named stealthd.

section.title: Linux Endpoint Requirements
section.para: This topic describes the Linux endpoint requirements.

formalpara.title: Supported Operating Systems
formalpara.para:
The following are supported Linux operating systems:
Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL)
RHEL 6.x, 32-bit and 64-bit
RHEL 7.x, 64-bit
For RHEL 6.x operating systems, Kernel level 2.6.32-431 or later is required. For RHEL 7.x operating systems, Kernel level 3.10.0-229 or later is required.
For RHEL 7.x operating systems, note that the Linux endpoint does not integrate with systemd. The /etc/init.d/stealthd service script is installed, and you should use the standard service commands to start, stop, or restart the stealthd service.
SUSE Linux Enterprise Server (SLES)
SLES 11.x, 32-bit and 64-bit
For SLES 11, you must run Service Pack 4 or higher.
SLES 12.x, 64-bit
For Stealth to operate, the SLES firewall must be disabled. To temporarily disable the firewall (for example, during testing), enter the following command: sudo rcSuSEfirewall2 stop
To disable the firewall permanently (for a production environment), enter the following commands as root, and then reboot your system: chkconfig SuSEfirewall2_setup off chkconfig SuSEfirewall2_init off
For SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 11.x endpoints, you must compile and install a required Kernel crypto module. Directions on how to do so are included in .
For SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 12.x endpoints, Kernel level 3.12.39–47 or later is required.
Ubuntu
Ubuntu 12.04 LTS, 32-bit and 64-bit
Ubuntu 14.04 LTS, 64-bit
For 64-bit Ubuntu operating systems to operate with Stealth, the AES-NI Kernel module must be disabled. section.title: Importing the Trust Chain for the Endpoint Package Signing Certificate on Linux Endpoints
section.para: A signing certificate is used to protect the integrity of the settings.xml and crypto.xml files, which are included in the endpoint software package. The XML files in the endpoint software package are signed, and that signature is verified by the signing certificate.

During the Linux endpoint installation processes, you are directed to do the following:
Obtain the trust chain for the signing certificate in PEM format.
The trusted root certificate for the default signing certificate that is created by Enterprise Manager is located on the Management Server in the C:\Stealth Files\Certificates directory, and it is named Unisys Stealth Root. You can copy the Unisys Stealth Root trusted root certificate from this directory and import it on each endpoint.
If you do not already have one in your environment, set up the CA certificate store. The certificate store can be a certificate file that contains the contents of the trust chain certificates, or it can be another method that is specific to your environment.
Import the trust chain certificates into the certificate store.
Specify the location of the CA certificate store in the /etc/stealth/system.ini file.

note.para: The signing certificate is automatically included in the endpoint package, which means that the signing certificate does not have to be imported on any endpoints.

section.para: See for directions on installing the Stealth endpoint software, including importing the trust chain certificates to the CA certificate store, and specifying the location in the system.ini file.

section.title: Linux Endpoint Initial Installation and Authorization Configuration
section.para:
To initially install and configure authorization settings for Stealth endpoint software on a server or workstation running a supported Linux operating system, do the following:
Ensure that you met all of the requirements for Linux endpoints in .
Obtain the endpoint installation file from the C:\Stealth Files\Software Installs\Packages directory on the Management Server.
Log on as root, and then open a terminal window.
Copy the endpoint installation file so that it is accessible from the Linux endpoint you are configuring.
You must copy the file using a binary format. If you use a program such as WinSCP to copy these files, ensure the Transfer Settings mode is set to Binary.
For example, you can do the following:
Copy the file from the Management Server to a USB storage device, and then connect the USB storage device to the Linux endpoint.
Enter the following command to list the drives connected to the Linux endpoint:cat /proc/partitions
Determine which drive is the USB storage device containing the Stealth software.
Enter a command like the following to mount the USB device. (In this example, the name of the drive is “sdb” and the drive is mounted to “mnt.”)mount /dev/sdb /mnt
Enter a command like the following to change to the directory where you mounted the endpoint installation file:cd /mnt
In this example, the name of the directory is “/mnt.”
Enter the following command to change the mode:
chmod +x <Linux endpoint installation file name>.sh
To install the Stealth software, enter the following command:./<Linux endpoint installation file name>.sh
The software is installed. When the installation is complete, you see a message that reads “Stealth configured.”
As described in , obtain the trust chain for the signing certificate (that is the Trusted Root certificate for the Certificate Authority and any intermediate certificates) and copy the certificate files to the endpoint.
If you do not import the trust chain on the endpoint as described below, the endpoint cannot be authorized and the Stealth service cannot be started.
Depending on your corporate policies, the trust chain might already be saved in an existing directory on your endpoint. Alternatively, you might have to mount a drive with the certificate files, using similar steps to those you performed earlier in this procedure to copy the endpoint installation file to the endpoint.
Do the following to verify that the trust chain certificate is in PEM format.
If you created a certificate on the Enterprise Manager Certificate tab, the certificate is already in PEM format.
Open the certificate in a text editor.
Verify that the certificate file includes “BEGIN CERTIFICATE” and “END CERTIFICATE” lines.
If these lines appear, the certificate is in PEM format. Skip the next step.
If these lines do not appear, the certificate is not in PEM format, and you must use openssl to convert the certificate into PEM format.
For example, enter the following command to convert a DER formatted certificate file to PEM format using openSSL:openssl x509 -inform der -in <certificate name>.cer -outform pem -out <certificate name>.pem
Where <certificate name>.cer is the certificate file in the DER format, and <certificate name>.pem is the converted certificate file.
As described in , do the following to create a CA certificate store and import the trust chain for the signing certificate.
If you currently use a CA certificate store to store public keys on your endpoints, you can use this existing directory. Alternatively, you can create a file (for example, ca-certificates.crt) to use as the CA certificate store.
If you want to use a certificate file as the CA certificate store, do the following to create the certificate file and import the trust chain certificates into the file:
Create a new certificate file (for example, named ca-certificates.crt) in the directory that includes the trust chain certificates, and copy the contents of each PEM format certificate in the trust chain into this file by entering the following command:cat <file name1>.pem <file name2>.pem <file name3>.pem > ca-certificates.crt
Record the name and location of the .crt file you used as the CA certificate store; you are instructed to specify this location in the system.ini file later in this procedure.
For SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 11.x endpoints, do the following to compile and install a required Kernel crypto module.
If your endpoints are running Red Hat Enterprise Linux, SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 12.x, or Ubuntu skip to the next step.
Install these software packages in the following order:
kernel-source
kernel-<flavor>-devel
To determine the SUSE Kernel “flavor,” enter the uname -r command in a terminal window. The Kernel flavor is the last hyphenated section of the command output (for example, if the result is 3.0.76-0.11-default, then the Kernel flavor is default.)
gcc
To install the Kernel module, execute the sles-ghash-install.sh script, which is located in the /etc/stealth/admin-scripts directory. Enter the following commands: cd /etc/stealth/admin-scripts ./sles-ghash-install.sh
If Stealth is running during the script execution, you must restart the Stealth service.
Although the Kernel module is compiled from official SUSE source code, the Kernel module is not supported by SUSE. Installing this module will put the Kernel in a tainted state; however, it is required to use Stealth on a SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 11.x endpoint.
Locate the sample configuration file called system.ini.example in the /etc/stealth/ directory.
Enter the following commands to copy the sample file and save it as system.ini:cd /etc/stealth cp system.ini.example system.ini
Do the following:
Launch an editor, and edit /etc/stealth/system.ini to define a set of authorization properties to enable authorization with the Authorization Service.
Under the version line, add the following line: modlist=authservice
The lines should appear like the following:[global] version=0.1 modlist=authservice
If it does not already exist, create a section named [authservice] and add the following properties: [authservice] type=keysrc module=authservice enabled=true
For more information about these parameters and their values, see the system.ini.example file.
If they do not already exist, under [authservice], also add a new “username” line and a new “passphrase” line (or modify the existing lines) as follows:username=user1 passphrase=password1
The example user is named “user1” and the example password is “password1.” Substitute your actual user name for “user1” and your actual password for “password1.” For a domain user, enter “domain\username” for “user1.” (Note that certain versions of the dependent Linux packages use two backslashes or one forward slash.)
The user name you enter here should be the same as a user name that is a member of the Active Directory group that appears in Stealth(aware).
These properties will be used to authorize with any Authorization Service defined in the settings.xml file.
For example, the file should appear like the following: [global] version=0.1 modlist=authservice
[authservice] type=keysrc module=authservice enabled=true username=user1 passphrase=password1
To specify the location of the CA certificate store that includes the trust chain certificates for the signing certificate, add one of the following lines to the [global] section of the file (above the [authservice] line):
If the CA certificate store is an existing directory, add the following line:ca_dir=<path/directory name>
For example, [global] version=0.1 ca_dir=/etc/ssl modlist=authservice
If the CA certificate store is a file (for example, if you created a certificate file earlier in this procedure), add the following line:ca_file=<path/file name>
For example,[global] version=0.1 ca_file=/etc/stealth/certs/ca-certificates.crt modlist=authservice
Save the /etc/stealth/system.ini file and close the editor.
By default, the /etc/stealth/system.ini file is readable only by root and group stealthd. Do not change the access permissions for this file.
Enter the following command to start the Stealth service:service stealthd start
For SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 12.x, enter systemctl start stealthd

formalpara.title: Enabling or Disabling Stealth on Boot
formalpara.para:
The Stealth service is configured to start when the system boots. To prevent the service from starting at boot, enter the following command:
For Red Hat Enterprise Linux and SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 11.x, enter the following command:chkconfig stealthd off
For SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 12.x, enter the following command: systemctl disable stealthd

To enable Stealth on a Red Hat Enterprise Linux, SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 11.x, or Ubuntu Linux system, enter the following command:service stealthd start
To disable Stealth on a SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 12.x system, enter the following command:systemctl stop stealthd
To enable Stealth on a SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 12.x system, enter the following command:systemctl start stealthd

section.title: Backing Up the Stealth(aware) Database
section.para:
It is recommended that you back up the Stealth(aware) database on a weekly basis or before making any significant changes to the database (for example, before importing new traffic data files or before using the Create Solutions tool). To back up the database, do the following:
Navigate to C:\Users\<user name>\AppData\Roaming\Stealth folder.
Copy the insight.db file to a secure location.
It is a best practice to rename this file in the secure location to append the date and time.
Do not change the name of the insight.db file in the C:\Users\<user name>\AppData\Roaming\Stealth folder.

If you need to restore this file, do the following:
Ensure that Stealth(aware) is closed.
Copy the file from the secure location in which you saved it, and paste it in C:\Users\<user name>\AppData\Roaming\Stealth.
Rename the file as insight.db.

section.title: Updating and Redeploying the Stealth(aware) Model

caution.para: Before updating the Stealth(aware) Model, ensure Live Feed is Off (from the Import Traffic Data tool).

section.para: If you need to update the Stealth(model) after deployment, you can do so at anytime and as many times as required for your environment using Stealth(aware).

The Discovery Agent and the Stealth endpoint software can run at the same time. However, if you are gathering information from Stealth-enabled endpoints, you must do one of the following:
Stealth-enable the file share that is collecting the network traffic data from the Discovery Agent
Create a clear text filter to the file share

note.para: Stealth-enabled traffic appears as encrypted traffic in Stealth(aware).

section.para:
After you import new network traffic data, you can use the modeling tools to make changes to the model; for example:
Import new network traffic data
Create new Solutions
Change the Affinity Level
Move Nodes into and out of Profiles
Move Profiles into and out of Solutions
When your updated Solutions are ready for deployment, you can use the Deploy tool to redeploy your Solutions.

section.title: Upgrading Stealth(Aware)
section.para: The following procedures describe how to upgrade Stealth(aware).

section.title: Upgrade Prerequisite for Stealth(aware) Version 3.2.004 and 3.2.010
section.para: If you are currently running Stealth(aware) version 3.2.004 or 3.2.010, perform the following prerequisite steps before performing the upgrade procedure. The Stealth(aware) software version is listed on the bottom of the Start Screen when you initially launch Stealth(aware).
If you are running a later version of Stealth(aware) software, skip to .

caution.para: If you do not perform these steps, upgrading from Stealth(aware) version 3.2.004 or 3.2.010 will remove all data from the database and permanently delete any projects that you previously created.

section.para:
Do the following:
Save the new version of the Unisys Stealth(aware) Release ISO to the system running Stealth(aware).
Mount the ISO file or extract the ISO file.
On the ISO file, navigate to the upgrade directory.
Copy the Run_Stealth-aware_upgrade.ps1 file from the ISO upgrade directory to any location on your system; for example, save it to C:\Windows\temp.
Open a PowerShell window and enter the following command: cd "<directory>"
For example, enter cd “C:\Windows\temp”.
Enter the following command:.\Run_Stealth-aware_upgrade.ps1
You receive a message that the database has been successfully saved and you must install the new version of Stealth(aware).
Close the PowerShell window.
Navigate to C:\Users\<user name>\AppData\Local\Stealth-<mm>-<dd>-<yyyy>_<hh>_<mm>_<ss>\app-3.2.0, and locate the insight.db database file.
Copy the insight.db database file from this folder, and paste it into the C:\Users\<user name>\AppData\Roaming\Stealth folder.

section.title: Upgrade Procedure

caution.para: If you are upgrading from Stealth(aware) version 3.2.004 or 3.2.010, perform the steps in before performing this procedure; otherwise, all data will be removed from the database and any projects you previously created projects will be deleted.
For Stealth(aware) version 3.2.0.11 or later, no prerequisite steps are required.

section.para:
To upgrade from your current version of Stealth(aware) to a new version, do the following:
If you have not already done so, do the following:
Save the new version of the Unisys Stealth(aware) Release ISO to the system running Stealth(aware).
Mount the ISO file or extract the ISO file.
On the new ISO file, double-click the Stealth-aware_Installer.exe file.
The new version of Stealth(aware) is installed and automatically launched.
Close Stealth(aware).
Launch Stealth(aware) from the icon on the desktop or by using the Start menu.
On the Stealth(aware) Start Screen, verify that the software version on the bottom of the screen has been updated, and verify that the Last Opened Project option includes the name of your most recently opened project. This indicates that Stealth(aware) version has been upgraded and your database has been successfully migrated.

Note the following:
If you upgraded from Stealth(aware) version 3.2.004 or 3.2.010, the previous version of the database is saved as described in .
If you upgraded from Stealth(aware) 3.2.011 or later, the previous version of the database is saved as insight_<revision>_<yyyymmdd>_<hhmmss>.db in the C:\Users\<user name>\AppData\Roaming\Stealth folder.

section.title: Restoring a Previous Version of Stealth(aware)
section.para: If you upgraded Stealth(aware), but you need to restore a previous version due to an issue with the database upgrade or due to an upgrade software error, you can perform this procedure to restore a previous version of Stealth(aware) and its associated database.

listitem.para: This procedure can only be used as documented to revert to a previous version of Stealth(aware) and its associated database. Do not adapt this procedure for any other purpose, and do not attempt to manually manipulate the database, or you might permanently corrupt your environment.
When you perform this procedure, any changes you made to the database since the upgrade will be lost.

section.para:
Do the following:
Navigate to C:\Users\<user name>\AppData\Roaming\Stealth and locate the insight.db database file.
Rename the database file; for example, rename it to before_restore_insight.db.
Perform the procedure in to delete the current version of Stealth(aware).
Using the ISO file that is associated with the version of the Stealth(aware) database that you want to restore, install that earlier version of Stealth(aware) software by performing the procedure in .
Launch Stealth(aware), and verify that the only available option is Create a New Project, as shown in .
Close Stealth(aware).
Navigate to C:\Users\<user name>\AppData\Roaming\Stealth and locate the insight.db database file.
Rename or delete the insight.db file.
This file was created as a new Stealth(aware) database during the installation process. Because you are restoring a previous database, this new version should not be required.
Do one of the following, depending on the version of Stealth(aware) that you want to restore:
If you want to restore a database associated with Stealth(aware) 3.2.011 or later, do the following:
Locate the insight_<revision>_<yyyymmdd>_<hhmmss>.db database file in the C:\Users\<user name>\AppData\Roaming\Stealth folder.
Copy this file and paste it in C:\Users\<user name>\AppData\Roaming\Stealth.
Rename the file as insight.db.
If you want to restore a database associated with Stealth(aware) version 3.2.004 or 3.2.010, do the following:
Locate the insight.db database file in the C:\Users\<user name>\AppData\Local\Stealth-<mm>-<dd>-<yyyy>_<hh>_<mm>_<ss>\app-3.2.0 folder.
Copy this file and paste it in C:\Users\<user name>\AppData\Local\Stealth.
Launch Stealth(aware), and verify that you see the Last Opened Project option, as shown in .
Your database is restored.

section.title: Updating Configurations Using the StealthConfiguration Utility

caution.para: In the following procedures, you must spell and capitalize all commands exactly as written.

Therefore, you might want to do the following:
Copy-and-paste these commands from this document into a text editor.
Update the variables for your environment.
Remove the line breaks.
Paste the resulting command into the command prompt window by right-clicking and selecting Paste.

section.para: As described in , you use the StealthConfiguration Utility to create a configuration for the Management Server and for the endpoints. If you need to create a new endpoint configuration or a new Administrative configuration, perform one of the procedures in this topic.

section.title: Deleting the Endpoint Configuration and Creating a New Endpoint Configuration
section.para:
If you want to delete the endpoint configuration and create a new one, do the following:
Ensure that you are logged on to the Management Server as a local administrator.
Open a command prompt using the Run as administrator option.
Enter the following command to access the StealthConfiguration Utility directory:cd "C:\Program Files\Unisys\EnterpriseMgmt\Stealth Manager"
Enter the following command to delete the endpoint configuration: StealthConfiguration.exe -v DeleteProject="<Endpoint Configuration Name>"
Ensure that you spell and capitalize this command exactly as written.
The -v option enables verbose mode and provides additional feedback on the results of the command. You should see feedback as the project is deleted.
For example, enter StealthConfiguration.exe -v DeleteProject="AwareEndpoints".
If you need to create any new clear text filters, do the following. For example, if the endpoints need to communicate with a Domain Name System (DNS) server that will not be Stealth-enabled, you can create a clear text filter.
Each clear text filter you create must have a unique name. You can create as many clear text filters as you choose, but you can only reference one clear text filter from the new endpoint configuration.
Each clear text filter can include one or more of the following, in a comma-separated list:
IP address – Enter one or more IPv4 addresses
IPv4 address range – Enter one or more IPv4 address ranges, separated by hyphen or using CIDR notation. For example, enter 192.0.2.8-192.0.2.16 or enter 192.0.2.0/24.
IP address with specific ports or protocols – Enter one or more IPv4 addresses or address ranges with port or protocol filters, using the syntax <IP address>:<protocol from 0 to 254> or <IP address>:<UDP or TCP>[<wild card or local port>:<wild card or remote port>]. For example, enter 198.51.100.3:20 or 198.51.100.3:TCP[*:53].
To create one or more clear text filters, do the following:
Enter the following command:StealthConfiguration.exe -v ClearTextFilterName="<Filter Name>" ClearTextFilter="<IP address or addresses>"
Ensure that you spell and capitalize these commands exactly as written.
The -v option enables verbose mode and provides additional feedback on the results of the command. You should see feedback as the filter is created.
Wait a brief time while the command is processed and the filter is created. When the processing is complete, you receive the command prompt.
If you need to create additional clear text filters, reenter the command using a unique filter name and an updated list of IP addresses.
For example, if you want to configure one filter set to communicate with a DNS server that will be used by both the Management Server and the endpoints, you could enter the following command:StealthConfiguration.exe ClearTextFilterName="DNS" ClearTextFilter="192.0.2.8"
In another example, if you want to configure one filter set for an Active Directory server for the Management Server, and configure a second filter set for the endpoints to communicate with the Active Directory server and with DNS servers on an IP address range using TCP port 53, you could enter the following command:StealthConfiguration.exe ClearTextFilterName="MS_AD" ClearTextFilter="192.0.2.10"
StealthConfiguration.exe ClearTextFilterName="EP_DNS" ClearTextFilter= "192.0.2.10,198.51.100.1-198.51.100.5:TCP[*:53]"
To create a new endpoint configuration, enter the following command:StealthConfiguration.exe -v StealthConfigName="<Admin Configuration Name>" UserAuthorizationPort=10300 IPAddress="<Management Server IP Address>" ProjectName=”<Endpoint Configuration Name>” ProjectClearTextFilterName= "<Optional endpoint filter>"
Ensure that you spell and capitalize these commands exactly as written.
The -v option enables verbose mode and provides additional feedback on the results of the command. You should see feedback as the configurations are created.

section.title: Deleting the Administrative Configuration, the Endpoint Configuration, and Creating New Configurations

caution.para: This is an advanced topic that requires extensive use of Enterprise Manager. Refer to the Unisys Stealth Solution Information Center for more information about performing any of the steps in this procedure.

section.para: If you need to delete the Administrative configuration and endpoint configuration you created using the StealthConfiguration Utility, you can uninstall and reinstall the Enterprise Management software from the Management Server. Alternatively, you can perform the following procedure.

When you perform this procedure, you delete all of the components you created when you ran the StealthConfiguration Utility, including the Administrative configuration, the endpoint configuration, and the Stealth endpoint packages. After you perform this procedure, you must redeploy using Stealth(aware) and install new versions of the Stealth endpoint packages on the Management Server and on all endpoints.

Do the following:
Ensure that you are logged on to the Management Server as a local administrator user.
Open a command prompt using the Run as administrator option.
Enter the following command to access the StealthConfiguration Utility directory:cd "C:\Program Files\Unisys\EnterpriseMgmt\Stealth Manager"
Enter the following command to delete the endpoint configuration: StealthConfiguration.exe -v DeleteProject="<Endpoint Configuration Name>"
Ensure that you spell and capitalize this command exactly as written.
The -v option enables verbose mode and provides additional feedback on the results of the command. You should see feedback as the project is deleted.
For example, enter StealthConfiguration.exe -v DeleteProject="AwareEndpoints".
Launch Enterprise Manager, and log in using portaladministrator credentials.
Do the following to delete the existing endpoint packages:
Select Manage from the menu bar.
On the Package tab, on the Endpoint Package subtab, press Ctrl and select all of the endpoint packages on the page.
At the bottom of the page, click Delete.
Click Yes to confirm the deletion.
Wait until the endpoint packages are deleted.
Do the following to delete the Administrative configuration:
Select Configure from the menu bar, and then select the Configuration tab.
Select the Administrative configuration (for example, AwareAdmin).
At the bottom of the page, click Delete.
Click Yes to confirm the deletion.
Wait until the configuration is deleted.
Do the following to delete the associated COIs:
On the Configure page, select the COI tab.
Select the first COI associated with the Administrative configuration (for example, AwareAdminLicenseCOI).
At the bottom of the page, click Delete.
Click Yes to confirm the deletion.
Wait until the COI is deleted.
Select the second COI associated with the Administrative configuration (for example, AwareAdminServiceCOI).
At the bottom of the page, click Delete.
Click Yes to confirm the deletion.
Wait until the COI is deleted.
Optionally, do the following to delete the clear text filters you created.
This step is optional, because you can create an unlimited number of clear text filters that use unique names. If you want to delete any clear text filters, be sure that you delete all associated filter sets, lists, and qualifiers.
Select Filters from the menu bar, and then select Filter Set from the Filter tree.
Select the first filter set on the right side of the page.
At the bottom of the page, click Delete.
Click Yes to confirm the deletion.
Repeat the previous two steps to delete all additional filter sets.
Select Filter List from the Filter tree.
Select the first filter list on the right side of the page.
At the bottom of the page, click Delete.
Click Yes to confirm the deletion.
Repeat the previous two steps to delete all additional filter lists.
Select Qualifier from the Filter tree.
On the Protocol/Port tab on the right side of the page, select the first qualifier in the list.
At the bottom of the page, click Delete.
Click Yes to confirm the deletion.

On the IP on the right side of the page, select the first qualifier in the list.

Repeat the previous two steps to delete all additional qualifiers on the IP tab.

section.title: Monitoring the Stealth Environment Using Enterprise Manager
section.para: Stealth(aware) does not support monitoring of the Stealth environment. To monitor the Stealth environment, you must use Enterprise Manager. For more information on using Enterprise Manager to monitor your environment, see the Unisys Stealth Solution Information Center.

section.title: Modeling New Environments
section.para:
If you are modeling a different network segment in the same environment, or if you are modeling a different environment, it is recommended that you create a new database file as follows:
Close Stealth(aware).
Use Windows Explorer to navigate to C:\Users\<user name>\AppData\Roaming\Stealth and locate the insight.db database file.
Rename insight.db to use a new name, for example, insight.db_<date> or insight.db_<client name>.
Launch Stealth(aware), and verify that the only available option is Create a New Project, as shown in .
This action will create a new insight.db database file. In this way, data is isolated and performance is maintained.
If you want to view the previous database file in Stealth(aware), repeat the previous steps, and rename the previous database file insight.db.

section.title: Troubleshooting Stealth(aware) Errors
section.para: If Stealth(aware) encounters any errors, use the information in this topic to understand and troubleshoot those errors.

entry.para: Error 001: There was an unexpected error and Stealth(aware) is not usable.
Due to a critical failure, Stealth(aware) is not usable.

listitem.para: Close Stealth(aware) and then attempt to relaunch it.
See for information on sending diagnostics to Unisys.
Uninstall and reinstall Stealth(aware).
See for information on restoring your previous environment.

entry.para: Error 101: There was an unsupported upgrade or downgrade attempt.
There was an attempt to upgrade Stealth(aware) from a version that is not supported, or there was an attempt to downgrade Stealth(aware).
See for information on restoring your previous environment.
Error 102: There was a template mismatch during an upgrade.
During a supported upgrade, an unexpected error condition occurred, and the upgrade process was compromised.

listitem.para: See for information on sending diagnostics to Unisys.
See for information on restoring your previous environment.
Obtain a new version of the ISO file, and then attempt the upgrade again.

entry.para: Error 103: The database could not be successfully migrated during an upgrade.
During a supported upgrade, an unexpected error condition occurred, and the database migration could not be completed.

listitem.para: See for information on sending diagnostics to Unisys.
See for information on restoring your previous environment.

entry.para: Error 201: The database could not be opened and might be corrupted.
Due to an attempted manual change to the database or a critical system failure, the database could not be opened.
See for information on sending diagnostics to Unisys.
There was an unexpected error when running the Create Solutions tool, if you used the Default (All Databases) option.

listitem.para: Close Stealth(aware) and then attempt to relaunch it.
See for information on sending diagnostics to Unisys.
See for information on restoring your database from a previously backed up version.

entry.para: There was an unexpected error when running the Create Solutions tool, if you used the Manually Select Profiles option.

listitem.para: Close Stealth(aware) and then attempt to relaunch it.
See for information on sending diagnostics to Unisys.
See for information on restoring your database from a previously backed up version.

entry.para: There was an unexpected error when running the Set Affinity Level tool.

listitem.para: Close Stealth(aware) and then attempt to relaunch it.
See for information on sending diagnostics to Unisys.
See for information on restoring your database from a previously backed up version.

entry.para: Error 304: There was an affinitization error after processing the following pcap file: <file name>
After the traffic data file was imported, the software attempted to affinitize the new data based on the value in the Set Affinity Level tool. An unexpected error then occurred.

listitem.para: Close Stealth(aware) and then attempt to relaunch it.
See for information on sending diagnostics to Unisys.
See for information on restoring your database from a previously backed up version.

entry.para: Error 305: There was an affinitization error after processing the pcap files imported using Live Feed.

After the traffic data file was imported using the Live Feed option, the software attempted to affinitize the new data based on the value in the Set Affinity Level tool. An unexpected error then occurred.

listitem.para: Close Stealth(aware) and then attempt to relaunch it.
See for information on sending diagnostics to Unisys.
See for information on restoring your database from a previously backed up version.

entry.para: Error 401: There was an error reading the following pcap file: <file name>
An error occurred when reading the traffic data file. The file is likely corrupted.

listitem.para: See for information on sending diagnostics to Unisys, including the file.
Attempt to import a different traffic data file.

entry.para: Error 402: There was a error reading the following pcap file imported using Live Feed: <file name>
An error occurred when reading the traffic data file using Live Feed. The file is likely corrupted.

listitem.para: See for information on sending diagnostics to Unisys, including the file.
Access the directory you configured in , and remove the corrupted file from the share.
Turn Live Feed on (it was automatically disabled when the error occurred).

section.title: Collecting Diagnostics for Stealth(aware)
section.para:
To report an issue to Unisys, you use a User Communication Form (UCF). To report an issue for Stealth(aware), create a UCF and attach the following files from the system running Stealth(aware):
The insight.db file in C:\Users\<user name>\AppData\Roaming\Stealth
The following files in C:\Users\<user name>\AppData\Roaming\Stealth\logs:
stealth-aware.log
stealth-aware-ui.log

section.title: Uninstalling Stealth(aware)
section.para: If you need to uninstall Stealth(aware), use the standard Windows method to uninstall a program. Stealth(aware) is listed as “Stealth” under Windows Programs and Features. The Stealth(aware) application and your associated project data will be deleted from the system.
In addition, use Windows Explorer to navigate to C:\Users\<user name>\AppData\Local, and then delete the Stealth directory.
